content:
r 8, 2016
												I feel disgusting. I've been beating homeless people and torture victims to death with a shovel in the ruins of a special ed school. This is so I can find a man missing an arm and part of his face so he can tell me about who did that to him, so I can find the guy hunting THAT guy. I might go back and do it all again, too, because I only found five of the six rotten bird carcasses hidden in that particular building.Welcome to Condemned: Criminal Origins, the most grotesque window into urban decay masquerading as a game I've ever experienced (and yes I've played Kingpin). You play FBI special agent Ethan Thomas as he tracks down a serial killer known as the Match Maker through the derelict underbelly of what I can only assume is Detroit. Your quest will take you through offices, schools, libraries, and estates, each one in an incredible state of disrepair. These ruins are populated with murderous hobos of all shapes and sizes, representing a mysterious psychosis affecting the city in relation to a plague of dead birds.If that all sounds insane, you've got a good idea of what you're getting into. The game starts with a clever forensics scene where you get to use a spread of investigative tools to extract clues from the Match Maker's latest tableaux. Immediately thereafter the game shifts to skulking through dark halls and clubbing people with rebar. You'll come across plenty more opportunities to use your forensics tools, of course, but those moments are islands in a sea of hobo blood. There are also simple puzzles to solve, often by finding a specific weapon like a crowbar or fire axe to pass a roadblock. Again, you're going to have to kill a dozen people to find it, though.Combat-heavy games are usually light on horror, but Condemned is a remarkable exception to that rule. The vast majority of combat is hand-to-hand, with firearms being rare and brief escapes from bludgeoning foes. You'll be armed just as your enemies are, with pipes pulled from walls or tools scrounged from garbage piles. Opponents often approach silently, lie in wait behind corners, and attack in groups, putting you at all sorts of disadvantages. But more than that, combat itself can be a tense and horrifying endeavor. Your character is fully modeled, meaning you have feet you can watch that slow you down when you turn or try to navigate stairs. This adds weight and a delay to your actions, along with a palpable sense of vulnerability. Hits also have weight to them, a sickening one at that, and your enemies grow more twisted as the game progresses.The atmosphere of acute urban decay becomes one of the most effective parts of the horror, when you have gaunt, deranged vagrants crawling out of sewer grates and breaking down rotten walls to crack your skull open. Condemned does a fantastic job of making you feel alone and threatened in a world that SHOULD be benign. A subway station after hours becomes a nest of crawling degenerates, with creepy treks down the darkened tracks and desperate searches just to get past a jammed door or turnstile. The sound design contributes in a big way, filling the air with subtle, ambient dread and holding back stingers until they're most effective.The few problems I do have with Condemned stem from its age. As good as the design is across disciplines, the graphics have aged rather poorly. The major characters are blurry, lumpy figures that resemble reskinned Gears of War characters for how bulky and hunched they are. You'll also be seeing a lot of the same garbage piles copy-pasted throughout the lengthy levels. And while you'll get a few chills out of seeing enemies scamper past the next doorway, they literally never stop using that spook and it actually starts to kill tension around the 30th time you see it.There's a lot more to recommend about Condemned than to criticize, of course. Both the horror and the combat are top-notch, the investigations are a great change of pace, the sound design is incredible (especially the voice overs, unexpectedly so), and the story helps keep you rolling forward even if it does end in a pretty weird place. It's far from the prettiest game out there, and some of the design is very clearly from earlier FPSes, but if that won't bother you there's six to eight hours of spooks and splatter to enjoy. Condemned did a rare thing for me, which was scare me in a way I wanted more of, and it deserves plenty of praise and attention for that.

content:
3, 2014
												Ever just want to rip a pipe out of a wall and crack someone over the head?   Don't try this at home or at your place of business :)While my play time on Steam will appear non existent, I have played Condemned every year since it's 2005 introduction. Containing multiple endings, Condemned, a first person psychological horror, offers the player a chance to experience some of the most well implemented melee combat that has ever been produced.  A great variety of melee weapons are available and weapons such as rebar, pipes and locker doors can be pulled literally right out of the environment.  Weapons are not limited to Melee.  Ranged weapons are limited in availability and include but are not limited to rifles, pistols and shotguns.  Ammo is limited to what is loaded in the weapon so shots count.  Run out of ammo?  Ranged weapons also double as melee weapons.  Melee weapons are rated by damage, swing speed, block time and reach.Condemned builds great atmosphere. Its story is told through the brilliance of forensic investigation using forensic tools and activley involves you in crime scene investigations. Condemned was released in 2005 and you can tell by the games character modelling however the environment that the game presents remains outstanding. The game's engine loads as fast as any engine I've seen and keeps load times to a bare minimum.  Great use of sound and nice visuals complement the immersive story.  The weapons of Condemned.In February 2008 all copies of Condemned were confiscated in Germany because of §131 StGB. Distribution in Germany is now prohibited by law.*Source:Wikipedia[en.wikipedia.org].

content:
r 25, 2014
												Okay, so you've probably heard of this game before. It was developed by Monolith Studios alongside F.E.A.R., so yeah, there's good things to expect here. You play as Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent stationed in NYC who's framed for the murder of two fellow police officers and is being chased by the Bureau while he attempts to find clues and follow the trail of the real criminal behind it all. The atmosphere is superb and full of creepy noises and heart-pumping suspense to go with the eerie locales including (but not limited to) an abandoned subway, an abandoned department store (WITH CREEPY AS ♥♥♥♥ TELEPORTING MANNEQUINS), an abandoned school... yeah a lot of abandoned areas, hence "Condemned". Complete with these areas are enemies galore, all of which are pretty much mentally screwed up drug addicts, both minor and major. The combat is satisfyingly brutal, crunchy, and has a great weight to it with every hit. It requires precision timing when blocking too, and takes a bit of practice to get it right. You can pretty much pick up anything layed about to use as a weapon (really, even a friggin' desk drawer) and firearms come into play later on. Weapons are plentiful, and health pill cabinets are found pretty easily throughout the game. It took about 8-9 hours to complete for me, so it's certainly every bit worth the price you pay, even if you don't get it on sale. Really, if you're a horror fan, this is a MUST BUY!

content:
er 28, 2015
												This was a game I picked up based on a bunch of recommendations from various imageboards and a few friends. For what it’s worth, Condemned: Criminal Origins lives up to the hype and immerses you in a world of filth, horror, and redemption. You play the role of Ethan Thomas, a FBI agent tasked with tracking down serial killers, who ends up wrongfully accused of a crime he didn’t commit. Your desire for exoneration drives you to follow a trail of madness with only your FBI lab tools and intuition to guide you.During the game, you will be spending your time doing one of the following: combat or forensics. In the combat phase, gameplay resembles that of a first-person shooter or beat-em-up requiring you to either aim carefully or time your blocking and movement so as to avoid taking damage. You also get a taser which is extremely useful in situations where you are facing groups or enemies with firearms. For the forensic phase, you will draw upon an array of tools to scan the surrounding area and collect the necessary information to continue the storyline. The implement used is automatically decided on depending on the circumstance and you are only required to point it at the very obvious area of interest in just about every instance, so there really isn’t much of a challenge. It’s basically just a vehicle used to drive the story forward. Regarding the story, everything is “good enough” and just about all the loose ends get tied up by the end so you won’t need to draw your own conclusions for the most part.Earlier in my backlog, I came across another murder mystery with a few similar themes (Deadly Premonition) and I’d have to say this is definitely the better of the two, at least story-wise. Be sure to pick it up if you want a little horror-mystery hybrid in your life.

content:
5, 2014
												Condemned is a deeply atmospheric and violent horror game. You're a crime scene investigator: you start off by visiting a crime scene and use forensic tools to determine what happened there. After the initial investigation you find out the suspect is still in the building and go to corner him, but in a turn of events he manages to grab your pistol and you get conked out. You wake up to find you're wanted for two murders you didn't commit and must now clear your name by tracking down this maniac killer through some of the eeriest parts of the city.Condemned is a standout game when it comes to horror because of its immersive level design. Environments are extremely well fleshed out and thick with atmosphere. The gritty realistic detail in textures is particularly impressive, especially for a 2005 game, and because the horror and scares are subtle and more psychological in nature there is a genuine tenseness when exploring a new area. Not to mention that most of the derelict places you wander through are so dark you're forced to go in with just a flashlight to light your way... it definitely recalls some of my creepier urban exploration adventures!


The emptiness is deceptive 
A Screenshot of Condemned: Criminal Origins
By: Meeps-a-Lot







Basement 
A Screenshot of Condemned: Criminal Origins
By: Meeps-a-Lot




Besides having an immersive horror atmosphere, Condemned shines in its brutal melee combat. It's especially impressive how realistic the enemies movements to your blows are. The most unique part of the combat is you can pull your weapon arsenal right from the environment: pry out a rebar pipe, rip the door from a locker, snatch a metal sign to get bloodied up - every location has its own host of makeshift weapons to put to good use. Oh, and I like that the enemy AI will fight each other if one of them accidentally hits the other - nice touch. Admittedly the gameplay when it comes to the forensic stuff is forcibly linear. They shoehorn you into only being able to use one type of scanner or tool when you have an array at your disposal and you are basically only doing it to move the story along. It's still fairly interesting and interactive though, and the findings you report will give you clues into what's really going on and what to do next.


:o 
A Screenshot of Condemned: Criminal Origins
By: Meeps-a-Lot




All in all, I recommend checking this out if you're looking to explore a genuinely tense game spiced up with savage melee encounters and an engaging story. If you've played FEAR you know these guys will deliver on a solid horror game.

content:
3, 2014
												Condemned: Criminal Origins features a story of a detective who ends up on the run due to strange circumstances. He's after a demented serial killer, and to catch him and clear his name, he must take to the underbelly of the city. However, something strange is going on. Homeless people that have taken to living in abandoned buildings and tunnels are acting needlessly aggressive and violent. But it's more than just that, something darker, more sinister is thriving in the unseen places of this city...Featuring a rather well-done and satisfying melee-focused combat system (seriously, not exaggerating, it has one of the best melee combat systems in a first-person type of game in my opinion), you'll find yourself exploring 10 different locations through the game, and periodically using some gadgets and gizmos for forensic sciences to try and track your killer. But of course, the best parts of the game aren't the combat or the detective work (though neither are bad!).The horror element in this game doesn't really fully reveal itself until the later half of the game, which I think is an interesting choice. The atmosphere in this game is fantastic for certain, but things start to get seriously creepy and a bit unpredictable about half-way in. It's interesting as most horror games like to sort of blow their load at the start and then fuel the survival element in the second half of the game with more and more difficult enemies. This game does get harder per say, but its horror element really starts to shine in its second half, and I even think there may be less enemies in the second half of the game as well.There are some very clever scares here, but honestly most of the horror comes from a really dreary atmosphere the game has, which is particularly strong in three specific locations/chapters in the later half. The story is interesting, though in this titles case I think you'll end off with more questions than answers (which might be for the best, as the sequel shows).It's not perfect. Most notably, the final chapter and boss are a bit disappointing (a shame as they're promising in concept but just not executed all that well), but the game is definitely worth checking out for any horror enthusiasts out there. Most of the title has excellent execution and atmosphere, and it truly is one of the best horror games to have released in the last 10 years.

number of helpful: 35 of 40 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
12, 2016
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first-person psychological horror game by Monolith, renown for kickstarting the F.E.A.R. franchise, where the player takes the role of Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent who gets framed by a serial killer for killing his colleagues during a crime investigation. This sets motion for the events that are to follow in which Ethan, guided by his only trustworthy ally who believes he was not behind the killings, has to hunt down the real serial killer. In the meantime, Ethan also begins noticing the sudden increase in some very peculiar events that occur around him and to almost every person he meets.As a survival horror, Condemned: Criminal Origins is a “beautiful” experience. What I mean by that is that the game focuses more on eerie atmosphere and enigmas reminiscent of games like Penumbra. No overuse of cheap jump scares and excessive gory imagery. For me, this is what I always wanted in a horror game which in recent years Frictional Games have always successfully provided for my fix. But even when the game ends up using these tropes for one or two occasions, they are well placed in the game and not overstay their welcome. Sure, the game also throws in a few supernatural elements, which I do not want spoil for obvious reasons, into the mix later on that make the experience even more petrifying. Frankly, there are quite a number of things which Condemned: Criminal Origins nails perfectly, and one of them is certainly the stellar audio design. The moment you hear all that tromping upstairs or around you, you truly start believing you could bend a steel pipe by how tense your butt cheeks are. I am not joking when I am saying that I occasionally pondered whether the real name of this game should have been Condemned: The Ferret Tromping. Likewise, the great soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and fits with the tone of the game. You can feel the cold shivers running down your spine. Bloody violins.When not wetting your pants like a sissy, Condemned’s gameplay is mostly all about melee encounters. Even though you can use a few firearms, their ammunition limitation makes them only worthwhile and effective in the short term. I suppose the best firearm is the taser as it can momentarily stun your enemies, giving you a window of opportunity to either steal their weapons or take an effortless shot at them, but it is useless against boss fights. Instead, you will be spending the majority of the time with melee objects such as pipes, planks, sledgehammers, axes, crowbars and many more, smacking your opponents to death. Whilst the melee combat might not feel exactly like in Chivalry: Medieval Warfare in terms of variety of moves, every swing has a “weight” to it. Thereby every miss you make can decide whether you will stay alive any longer. Now each weapon in the game has its own benefits and downsides. Some can deal more damage but are slower to manoeuvre and others deal less damage but are swifter. Honestly, the melee combat is perhaps amongst the best aspects of this game as it makes you think and move tactically. It feels satisfying too.For a horror game, I think the AI in here is exceptional. Most of the human enemies will try to play hide and seek rather than simply attacking the player the moment they are spotted. Moreover, they do not just hide in one spot; they constantly switch their positions. This makes encounters unpredictable and always different in each playthrough. Naturally, there are a couple of scripted moments designed specifically to scare the player in the game, but thankfully these are very few.In terms of graphical fidelity, the game shows its age quite clearly. There is no denying in saying that it feels visually “consolised” as the textures do look all muddy and the excessive bloom (when turned on) reminds me of games on a Xbox 360 from 2006. But in terms of art direction, it does a good job on the various designs of the enemies you can come across and the environments that almost feel like you actually visited them in real life. Additionally, the second half of the game, from a level design stand point, is much better and scarier.Of course, the game is not without its fair share of problems. First off, there are sections in the game which require you to take down some sort of a obstacle like a (wooden) door to advance to the next area. Being in the possession of an axe most of the time, at least in my case, one would think that would suffice. But you thought wrong as the game explicitly tells the player that it requires a specific weapon, like a sledgehammer, to take it down instead. This leads to going back and doing a couple of fetch-quests looking for the right item. Plus, you cannot guess what item  will require next time. Luckily, the aforementioned item generally tends to be nearby. Now, my main gripe with this is the simple fact that it is purely stupid. I have an axe, why cannot I take it down? Why do I need a different weapon which has pretty much an identical function as an axe in the game’s context?Then there is Ethan’s walking pace and stamina. The game gives the player the ability to sprint, but only lasts as long as “running” from one end of the room to the next.  It is not even running; it is a very slow jog. You see, it totally makes sense walking slowly in the more atmospheric segments of the game where you are in a pitch dark environment holding your melee weapon and a flashlight in hopes that nothing will startle you, but there are many occasions where that is not necessary -- such as when you have to backtrack in areas which you have already cleared out. This can be rather irritating when you are forced by the game to walk so slowly. It feels like the developers were somehow scared that people would sprint their way through the game, breaking the immersion they tried to achieve.The next issue which I am about to discuss is not too serious, but the forensics investigations in this game are sadly meaningless since you are always told where and what to search for. Take your scanning equipment, focalise it on the object you want to analyse, press click and presto you are the greatest forensics specialist in the world. Personally, I strongly believe this is where the game missed its biggest opportunity to deepen its gameplay. Not only that, but it could have made you feel almost like a detective, looking for clues and making deductions.Being a very linear game is not an excuse for the repetitive gameplay. The melee combat is definitely fun and rewarding, but after a few hours you will realise that smacking people’s heads and balls is what you will be doing almost the entirety of the game. It can get tiresome after a while due to the lack of variety. Because of that, the level design can also feel a bit too claustrophobic at times with its very narrow corridors and awful FOV. See, this is where a more complex and appealing forensics mechanic could have been handy to bring some proper variety.And lastly, while the game’s story starts out very promising, leaving the player with many questions and interpretations, it falls flat right towards the end. You can already smell the Indigo Prophecy stench from miles away, and that is one nightmare I try to not remember. The approach of “show, do not tell” which is adopted in the first three quarters of the game is well executed, because you know, a mystery is ruined the moment you bluntly explain it, but the ending kind of ruins most of that. I even think the last scene of the game nullified your entire journey.In conclusion, Condemned: Criminal Origins ticks all the boxes for a solid psychological survival horror game. Despite some questionable design choices and a rather abysmal ending, it is singlehandedly one of the scariest experiences out there, and I am not saying that lightly. Clocking around 6-8 hours, I would say that it has about the right length, so if you like horror games, pick this one up.

content:
er 4, 2014
												Ah the good old classical condemned criminal origins, a game not many people know of. A hidden gem as some call it.Storyline 10/10The storyline of the game is perfect, it has it's twists and surprises. You start off as agent thomas who's been framed for second degree murder and is being hunted down by the bureau. If you enjoy detective work and a great meaningful story this game is for you!Controls 7/10The controls for the game could have been better thought of, what annoyed me a little was the fact that there is no jump button...You use spacebar to kick. Another thing that seemed strange to me was the reload system, there is none. If you press the button R it just shows you how much ammo is left in the gun. What could have imporved it was if you could transfer one ammo clip into a different gun or just put it in your pocket.A.I. 8/10Its funny how the A.I.works in the environment of the game, they use walls and small debris to hide. I did notice the A.I. running around one box trying to figure out how to catch me better xDGraphics 10/10I honestly can't complain about the graphics, they were amazing. There is an option to set the graphics to the lowest where you can barely see the outline of a gun or set them to highest and see a loose screw on the ground. Options 10/10The game offers plenty of options to change the sound, graphics, difficulty. Unfortunately you can't change the fov ingame, you have to manualy go into the folder and change settings.Gameplay 9/10The gameplay is one of the most important parts of the game and this game got it perfectly, I didn't find a moment while playing where I was bored. As I stated earlier you are a detective so that means you get to do some detective work right? YEAH! You're mission is to catch the one who framed you, serial killer X and you do so by following clues hes left behind. Somehow you have pockets the size of buckets. Every time you find a clue you take out a different machine or device to catch fingerprints or dna samples which you send to your partner in crime, Rosa. Following up all the clues you start to wonder who the serial killer X really as. (It tells you at the end of the game.) This game took me 15 hours to complete without rushing and dying over and over xDFinal Verdict 8/10This game is something else, a game not many people realize has potential. If you ever get the chance you should play it. I had a lot of fun and many raging moments in the game, but that's just me being a noob xD

content:
10, 2013
												One of my favorite horror video games. It's a really dark and twisted murder mystery in first-person perspective, with a lot of beefy and satisfying melee combat. The combat is very engaging and intense with smart enemy AI, almost like a fight in real life would feel like. There are guns too, but you can't rely on them completely since ammo is limited and hard to find. So when you do happen to have a gun to use, it is a special privilege. So you mainly have to resort to grabbing some 2x4 or pipe in the environment and whack some foos, usually freaky ♥♥♥ deranged hobos and psychotic killers.You also have a bunch of very neat investigator tools and a taser that aren't just tacked on gimmicks; these mechanics actually make the gameplay very different from other FPSs. The investigation work brings some adventure/puzzle aspects to it. In fact, calling this game an FPS really doesn't describe the game as well as it ought to, nor does calling it a survival horror game or an adventure game. It's quite a special blend of all those aspects. And yes, it is scary. One of the scariest video games I can think of. And with a compelling story, if you ask me.If you like Monolith's F.E.A.R. series, Condemned is made by those very same people and is every bit as good (perhaps even better, in terms of a horror game). If you want to play something unique and different (and also really good) in the FPS or horror genres, I highly recommend Condemned. Unfortunately, the also very very fun (but more action-y and melee combat-focused) Condemned 2 never got a PC version. Maybe someday, I hope...

ry 16, 2016
												Good non-traditional horror game with one major flaw--it's the same thing over and over and over again.  Still, that thing (winding through the environment and fighting) is done really well, so I recommend the game.Melee combat is pretty challenging, and you'll likely die here and there. It's kind of one of those old school deals where you learn from your mistakes. The weapons, and there are a ton of them, all have their own feel, swing at different speeds, and are fun to use.  The health system is well designed. You always seem to find med packs when you really need them.  Overall, level design is really clever for a linear game with very little backtracking.Looking at this before purchase, I wondered how scary it could be running into homeless people.  Turns out, it's pretty darn scary, particularly in areas where the environment opens up and you can hear someone but can't figure out where the noise is coming from.  Sound plays a key role in the scares.To conclude, if you don't mind that the gameplay is basically the same all the way through, it's a good get for horror fans.

												It's been a while since I completed this game but I never took the time to write a little recommendation. I think it deserves one. It's a bit of an underrated game but it's also not your typical FPS. This is all about brutal and satisfying melee combat with an occasional gun you pickup that contains a handful of bullets at most. You also have some fancy equipment at your disposal for your forensic research. The games is developed by the same studio that brought us the first two F.E.A.R. games, wich is clearly noticeable. The game can be absolutely terrifying at times with a memorable jumpscare later in the game. If you are interested in an FPS with an intriguing story, you like the idea of a heavy focus on melee combat and you can live with heavily outdated graphics, this is definitely worth to take a look at.

content:
27
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first-person survival horror game developed by Monolith Productions and published by Sega. Released for the Xbox 360 on November 16, 2005 (and a PC port on April 11, 2006), it got mostly positive reviews for its atmosphere and the emphasis on melee combat, and was a moderate success for Monolith Productions. It went on to be considered as a classic of the survival horror genre, and is frequently mentioned as one of the scariest games on the market.What I Liked(+)The game starts strong; the first few cutscenes and gameplay sections present the story in an intriguing manner, and the tense atmosphere is consistent throughout the campaign.(+)Simple gameplay mechanics, but has some depth to it because of various weapon statistics like speed, blocking power, and damage; the enemy also has different behaviors and attack patterns, forcing the player to be tactical, rather than aggressive. Emphasizes melee combat over guns; there are only 1-3 guns available per level, and usually have low ammo if picked up.(+)The AI is as smart and cunning as those in F.E.A.R. (another Monolith Productions game) and behaves in a convincing manner. The player encounters a lot of aggressive drug addicts during the game, and they will make sure that your brain is splattered all over the wall by any means necessary; be it by hiding in the darkness to ambush you, whacking the back of your head when you're not looking, and disguising themselves as part of the environment for the perfect surprise. A neat way to deal with their numbers is to trick an enemy into hitting the fellow by his side, and they'll take their sweet time sorting that problem out - mainly in the form of a steel pipe to the face.What I didn't Like(-)Loses its traction near the end, and quickly shifts its tone from a slow-paced crawl to an adrenaline-fueled murderfest.(-)A lot of levels feels like filler content; added for the sake of prolonging the game. Throughout its 10 chapters, only a half of those actually presented something valuable to the overall story. Everything else is a walk through a checklist of places where spooky stuff might happen.And there you have it.

content:
r 24, 2014
A pretty cool horror game with a story that has its pretty unfitting moments and an odd ending that didn't seem to make sense I found.The plot for the whole thing is pretty simple, you're framed by a killer of two cops and you're on a journey to find him. Throughout that journey you experience weird shtuff that can mess your trousers quite a bit. The story itself is actually a bit interesting to say the least however I don't feel that it was told all that well whatwith it just being a bit slow on the telling despite how somewhat short the game itself is (like 6-8 hours).As for the actual gameplay it's an extremely simple first person, mostly melee based combat; they attack, you time your block right, you get a chance to attack some more until they're down. If you're good enough you can have them start fighting each other. There are guns in the game but they're very limited and restraint; you can't collect ammunition and you can't reload them though you can turn them into very fragile melee weapons. The entire game itself is pretty linear and it has a habit of having you backtrace (ie. acquire item X from this location to open door Y that you passed through a little earlier) though I didn't find it to be unbearably strenous. Because you're a Serial Crimes Unit agent you'll also be using investigation tools to partake in some CSI stuff by finding evidence that the person who framed you left behind which what you find that advances the plot further can be interesting.The real selling point of this game however is the survival horror part; you start to hallucinate spooky shtuff, most of where you go gets extremely claustrophobic & obviously dark, and the game can be downright freaky to move around in. For the most part I found it very uneasy to even go where I was supposed to and more uneasy whatwith me being a bit bad with the subject of horror in general. That's how I prefer my horror anyway, making you feel terrified as opposed to using petty jump scares (though I tend to be bad with those as well and plus there aren't too many in this game I found).Get it for when it's cheap.

content:
, 2014
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a very nice surprise for the discounted price of 3 buck something. Yeah I’m dat cheap. But I hadn’t even heard about the game until this Steam daily deal popped up. I had this vision for the original F.E.A.R. when the game came out, it was the wrong vision. I pictured a game sort of like Half-Life 2 where you walk through a creepy environment without hair raising moments and minimalistic shooting with a focus on a horror story telling.Turns out Condemned: Criminal Origins was the original F.E.A.R. I was looking for. It was practically released at the same time as well, circa 2006. I’m guessing development was somewhat parallel.It uses the Lithtech Jupiter EX game engine that I completely endorse … aside from the stutter-like frame rate, given the fact I didn’t feel this present in F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin (which I highly enjoyed) it must have been some bug inherent to the engine’s flagship release batch. There are 4 different types of saves which are very handy, but the Auto-Save will usually suffice on normal difficulty.As with F.E.A.R. 2, I must say that I have been quite impressed at the amount of content that is presented level design-wise. Whenever you progress through the game, they (Monolith?) always manage to change the scenery completely and smoothly. One moment you might be outside in some playground, the next you find yourself in some school’s locker hallway, then the next you find yourself in some bloody basement. All in one map with different 3D models and textures. That’s something you don’t find often in a lot of games which choose to repeat the scenery until the next level loads.I really don’t want to ruin this game for anyone, but Condemned: Criminal Origins had probably one of the most original boss fights I had seen in a long time. It looked heavily inspired by what I would call Sinawali (a Filipino martial arts involving sticks/batons). Most of the game combat-wise is based on melee strikes and blocking. Sometimes you will find some guns with a few shots, to which you are able to use its stock as melee on enemies that aren’t wielding a gun themselves. You also carry a Taser which is very handy for stunning your enemies for a few seconds (or frying bladder weak enemies). Although a bit of an eye-candy, there are also four optional finishing moves. The key word being optional … which some games don’t give. Add some sidekicks into the mixture and what you have is a fairly interesting combat system.Enemy AI is impressive, they fight each other if one accidently gets hit by another. They also somehow crawl through the bottom of bookshelves and attack by popping out half way. Some even disguise themselves in a creepy abandoned store by standing still amongst mannequins. Crazy huh?I’d say the story was mildly entertaining. It perhaps was a little slow to start off with in the beginning, but it just keeps getting better and better, including what was written during level loading screens. There are some basic investigations done like clue finding on certain visual cues. I’d give bonus points for this to the developers as to be totally honest I’m sick and tired of games infested with Full Motion Videos. Maybe that was okay back during the PlayStation days when it was difficult to include videos in games on other gaming platforms … but these days I’d prefer more interaction to my story. And this game hits the spot with that. It wasn’t hair raising or shocking … it was just good old fashion creepiness to build endless suspense. Of course there were some cut scenes, but the game wasn’t entirely saturated with them. The cut scenes happened at the appropriate times in my opinion.Excellent job done in the sound department. They are definitely responsible for the creepy atmosphere to the game without creating edge of your seat moments.I think my only quarrel with the game was perhaps the weapon, hand, phone and character 3D models. LOL, I’m not sure what the artists were thinking, they kind of just looked like 3D box modeling monstrosities with baked textures applied to them. At times I couldn’t even tell if I was holding a crowbar or a snake with a head defect. But it hardly takes away from the atmosphere.Overall a very relaxing 7 hour experience. If you haven’t played this game before and enjoy being in a horror-like crime environment that won’t make you jump out of your chair with the sight of things like Alma Wade … then this is a must have.

content:
ber 12, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: Monolith Publishers: SegaInitial release: April 2006Genre: Horror, Melee, FPS#Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationThe setup of Condemned is you play as Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent investigating a crime scene. In a rousing turn of events the perpetrator takes your gun and frames you for the murder of 2 of your follower officers and thus your adventure begins.  Condemned is not super long, roughly 5-7 hours depending on how long you spend doing side objectives. The game basically revolves around the cycle of investigating things for the purpose of clearing your name and well.. smashing faces with pipes. The gameplay mostly revolves around using melee attacks and while there are firearms, ammo is scarce and not always the most efficient defense. You are also afforded a taser effective at range for use of stunning and disarming other armed enemies. The enemies are all basically insane for narrative reasons I'll let the game expound upon. However, because of this behavior they often will start fighting with themselves and end up smacking one of the other enemies with a conduit in the back of the head affording you a much easier fight. The normal difficulty is not especially difficult. The animations are generally easy to read and a well timed block will set you right. Plenty of health packs as well; Not to mention quick save. This was my second playthrough and I had originally played on the X360. Some remnants of that version can be seen in that you spend some time looking for collectibles; Finding and unlocking achievements that aren't really marked anywhere as the PC version doesn't have achievements but still exist in the game. It's a minor complaint but one that feels out of place and worth mentioning. The game is indeed quite dated and for obvious reasons could use a texture overhaul. However, the gameplay is still great and the story engaging. Getting it to run in the resolution you desire my prove a bit finicky as the nature of the port seems to have minimal graphical options. THE GISTCondemned is one of those games I have a bit of nostalgia for and I'm glad to see it hold up 10 years later.Follow my curation for more

content:
9, 2016
												Don't look my Steamìs hours, I played this game so much on Xbox 360.Videogames definitely aren't just for kids any more. If that wasn't obvious after the barrage of 18-rated releases over the last few years, Condemned takes a gas pipe and beats you around the head until it's all too painfully obvious. Imagine the crazed villagers from Resident Evil 4 but more demented, visceral melee combat with the most brutal weapons ever seen in a videogame, dark and gloomy environments that could have been ripped from the most grim of horror movies, a heavy dose of the surreal, and then experience it all from an immersive first-person perspective. Condemned has already freaked out Xbox 360 owners, but PC gamers aren't safe any longer.As agent Ethan Thomas you're called to investigate a strange murder scene where the victim has been set up with a mannequin to create a dinner scene. After collecting evidence, noises are heard in the apartment above you, and a short fight later two cops have been shot dead with your gun, the killer has escaped and you're the prime suspect. Back at your apartment you start to see things and a mysterious man appears with stories about your special powers. With the cops on your back and the mysterious Vanhorn advising you to flee through your window, you set out to find the killer and clear your name.The game then uses the premise of brutally beating up violent mind-altered tramps, drug addicts and other members of society that the world has left behind, and sticks with it for its duration. You don't get much explanation for this, other than information on a disease that's killing birds and seems to be infecting humans too (albeit only those living on the streets). The actual core storyline revolving around the murders moves along nicely as you fight enraged tramps through a tube station, a shop, a school and more. It's all pretty grim stuff and over the ten or so hours it'll take you to get through it, you'll predominantly be smashing enemies in the face with blunt weapons and occasionally getting hold of a gun of some sort.It's certainly not going to win any awards for its depth of gameplay, but when this basic concept is so entertaining, it's easy to see why Monolith (the studio behind last year's F.E.A.R.) didn't try to add any more complexity. One button swings your weapon or fires your gun, another raises your weapon to block an enemy attack, and you have access to a taser (momentarily halting an enemy) that comes in very handy, particularly against enemies carrying guns. If you're brave enough you can kick enemies, knocking them to the ground and enabling you to brutally kill them with one of four finishing moves. These aren't essential to your progression, but they do add some variety to proceedings.The only diversion from the relentless beating is the odd bit of crime scene investigation. This is handled very well, but it's more or less given to you on plate, with the game prompting you whenever you can whip out some high-tech gadgets. Responding to the on-screen cue will make Ethan take out the tool he needs and then it's simply a matter of looking for something that shows up under the light, following the smell of rotting flesh using your detector, taking a sample or something similar. Your findings will be instantly sent over to Rosa, your friend in forensics, and she'll give you her findings with calls to your cell phone, giving you little titbits of info on the killer you're tracking. Given that the focus of Condemned is clearly the frenzied combat, the simple nature of the actual detective work is understandable, but some more depth would have added an extra dimension to the gameplay.There's not much light in Condemned, but the little there is, is used incredibly well. In trademark survival horror fashion every environment is dimly lit, with each object casting a menacing shadow. When you do see some brightness it's often blinding, offering little comfort over your previous adventuring in the dark. Fabulous lighting aside, Condemned does all it can to unsettle you: the psychotic enemies all look a little worse for wear and move with striking realism, blood and human remains litter the environment, everything looks trashed and a creepy black and white picture effect crops up from time to time, if only to mess with your head some more.You could dissect the game's presentation and pick out some frame rate problems and the odd dodgy texture, but when you're playing you really don't care. When a tramp smashes through a wall and charges at you holding a nail ridden plank of wood, the last thing on your mind is how next-gen it all looks. It's all made more unnerving by some truly deranged sound effects and horrible, meaty sounding combat. Round this off with some impressive voice acting from the main characters, and you've got one impressive package.As with Monolith's previous PC game F.E.A.R., you're going to need a high-end PC to play this as it was intended. A steady frame rate can be achieved by cutting back some of the more advanced features, but you end up losing some of the atmosphere that makes the game so great to begin with. Condemned moves at a slower pace than a traditional FPS, so you can get away with a less than spectacular frame rate. Be aware that the game forces you to play in widescreen, and unless you're using a widescreen display, the game will feature black bars at the top and bottom of the screen.Condemned delivers an experience that's worlds apart from what is usually on offer for PC gamers. At its core it's about as simple as a game could be, but it's presented in such a deranged and immersive way that it's hard not to get caught up in it all. Smacking someone around the face with a spade and watching blood spray from their mouth is a sight that will give many people the wrong view of videogames in general, but if you're old enough to play it and can stomach it, there's plenty of perverted pleasure to be had from Condemned.

content:
, 2016
												10/10 just for the AI.  You really feel like you are being stalked and every sound you hear causes you to frantically survey your surroundings.  As you get further into the game, there are more enemies per room and so you become desensitized to seeing shadows cross an empty hallway or hearing footsteps around you.  I wish they would have limited the interactions with enemies and made them more dangerous (remove the tazer) so that you are always on edge when those types of situations arise.  That being said, this is very much an atmospheric horror game that doesn't rely on jump scares (although there are a few of those too).  You are scared of what's around the next corner, even if you do become desensitized to some of the visual and audio cues.I've finished the game.  The story is engaging and the AI is incredible.  If a third Condemned is released, I hope they focus more on atmosphere and less on action.

12, 2014
												Although Dead Island was the first of it's kind that I played, it wasn't as realistic with the melee combat that this game prides itself in. Condemned has an excellent story, lots of action, superb AI, challenging achievements, and some mighty good scares. Did I mention the AI? Of course, I did. The AI is unlike any other game I've played. I love how your enemies can fake you out during battle. It sure keeps you focused, and every fight is a new experience. It's not as if your enemy has a set pattern that you can conquer in a couple tries, no! It's unpredictable and will push you to try different fighting techniques. Timing is key with the fighting system. And don't be fooled into thinking you can just whoop multiple guys at once like you're Jackie Chan or Bruce Lee...no, sometimes you have to RUN to survive. Choose your battles wisely, as well as your weapon. Choose the wrong one, and you can say "Goodbye".If you like unique gameplay, good concepts and storyline, and immersive atmospheres, then pick this one up. I'm sure glad I did.

												It's been a while since I've played a good horror game. Condemned: Criminal Origins was able to raise the hair on my arms with its creepy atmosphere, sounds, lighting, and supernatural events. Then there are the humanoids that crawl around on all fours--a chill shot up my spine every time I encountered one.You play the role of a detective investigating serial killers. One of them ends up framing you for murder and in your struggle to gather evidence to clear your name, you discover there is something even more sinister lurking out there. The story evolves slowly and constantly applies a state of terror that had me peeking around each corner to make sure the coast is clear. There are also some cool crime scene evidence gathering aspects to the game that kept it engaging.The game highlights melee focused combat allowing you to use pretty much any makeshift item as a weapon. There are also a few guns that can be found, but you won't find any extra ammo lying around so it's important to make your shots count. The game provides an extremely large number of enemies to bash through. Near the end, it almost hit a point of ridiculousness. But reaching the story finale was well worth it.Any fan or horror should not pass this one up.

content:
4, 2016
Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first-person horror game that I recommend a lot!Gameplay It's a first-person beat-em-up game and also a FPS when you'll get guns.There are many melee weapons available in the game which you can find all over the levels,and also guns which are usually hidden around or you can get them from enemies.You also have a taser gun which is very useful when you want to stun and disarm enemies.Combat is really fun and challenging,when enemies swing at you,block/parry with RMB and quickly press LMB to attack them back.Each weapon has different stats(damage,speed,block,reach),and sometimes you must carry one specific weapon(like an axe) to be able to open some doors or locks.One thing I don't like in this game is that you can't carry more than one weapon,so if you want to take with you a pipe and a rifle,it's too bad,you can't.I've also found annoying the fact that enemies seem to have a longer melee weapon reach than you.After beating an enemy,there is a chance he'll fall on his knees and allow you to do a finisher.You can do one by walking in front of him and pressing the key shown(1-Ram, 2-Slam, 3-Snap, 4-Punch).  Beside all the beating and gunning,you must also invenstigate clues(fingerprints,fluids,particles,etc.)and crime scenes using investigation tools like laser light,UV light and a camera.During the game you can also search for collectibles.There are 2 collectibles available: dead birds and metal pieces.In every level/chapter you can find 6 dead birds and 3 metal pieces.(There are 10 levels in total)Story You are Ethan Thomas, a crime scene investigation agent which you must journey through some condemned buildings in the search of a criminal who framed you for murder,the Serial Killer X.The story is pretty good and overall it's...well,horror.It has some quality jumpscares here and there that made me jump a little.The game is quite short,I've beaten it in 8 hours.It has 10 levels/chapters and it's linear.It can get a little repetitive if you play too much in one sitting.Graphics&Sound Since it's a 2006 game,it doesn't look that great,some textures are blurry and low res.But it isn't bad either.The sound effects are great and realistic,very atmospheric,you can hear whispers,screams,footsteps,etc. throughout the game.Conclusion - It's a great horror game with good story and great combat mechanics.I'd say it's a 8.5/10.

content:
7, 2016
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is pretty cool, I guess.You play as Ethan Thomas, an SCU Agent on the trail of an illusive serial killer that kills other serial killers. It's not the Punisher, though, that would be way too cool. 90's cool! Unlucky for Ethan, every hobo in the city is out for blood, either Ethan's or each others, and are causing havoc and violence across the city. I stole way too many television sets that night. I made a television fort. Your authority is not recognized in fort CNN. Guns and ammo are limited, so Ethan is forced to get down and dirty with said murder hobos through the use of melee weapons he finds in the environment. Each weapon has a set up stats that tell you it's total killing potential. Weapons also have a certain amount of durability before breaking, forcing you to find a new 2x4 or lead pipe to bash some poor man to death with. Your abilities are limited to a few moves, an attack, a defense, and a taser button that, by golly you're going to abuse, as well as a super kick that allows you to knock your enemies skulls out the back of their heads if the weapon just isn't doing it for you. The entire game is in first person, only leaving the view for cutscenes. While the combat itself is very basic, it makes up for it by being, pardon my buzzwords, very visceral and brutal. Hitting a hobo with your weapon has that mandatory crunch to it. Enemies react, stagger, and tumble around after being hit. Teeth fly from their mouths, their blood splatters across the floor, and they get very cross with you if you didn't outright kill them with your lead pipe or fire ax or human arm or whatever you got your hands on. The game calls itself a horror game. Then again I call myself a rich man who doesn't eat garbage but that doesn't make it true. It's very dark and atmospheric, but it's not really, well, scary. I never jumped or had a lets player level squeal while playing it. The environments are unsettling, but I never felt intimidated or frightened while going through hobo dens or subway tunnels. There is also an investigation segment that pops up every now and then. But it's never so in depth or complicated to make it anything more than a plot tool. Should you play, evicted: Conman beginnings? It's made by the guys who made FEAR back in the day, and it kind of shows. It's a pretty neat little game, especially considering it was a Xbox 360 launch title back in the day. I think. Was it? It's not ground breaking or overly amazing. But it's worth at least one play through. Condemned: Criminal origins receives 7 hobo battles out of 14 or something. Give me your old TVs, Fort CNN must become stronger. The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												Mixed feelings for this game, mixed feelings...First of all it seems to run on the F.E.A.R. engine, which is cool but then I'm baffled at how low quality the textures are, especially on the characters. Its like the environment uses way higher quality textures than the characters do. Isn't it supposed to be the other way around? Or why can't everything just look fine, instead it puts the supposed F.E.A.R. engine to shame by using blurry and low as hell textures on characters. F.E.A.R., for example looked better and it came out like a year earlier than this. Well enough of nitpicking at some of the visuals, cause to be honest most of the game visually looks pretty decent, but now on to other things.This game seems to do somethings more or less unique like for example: Ammo is pretty damn limited, and there isn't even such thing as getting ammo or reloading your guns. Instead you pick up guns from wherever, or from enemies you kill and they may or may not have a full clip in it. Also enemies can ACTUALLY RUN OUT OF AMMO! WOW! So if you kill an enemy that has a gun fast enough before he attempts to waste ammo on you, you can benefit from it and have a more full clip of ammo. Its like literally one of the first games I've seen do that for enemies. I wish more games did that. I'm staring at you Half-Life 1 and 2, where the HECU soldiers and Combine soldiers infinitely pull clips of ammo and grenades out their ♥♥♥ without instead eventually running out of ammo and doing some well coded melee fighting with you.Most of the time you have to rely on melee weapons and its somewhat dodgy mechanic of combat, but for the most part it works. You can die fairly easily, especially from certain weapons so you do not want to take combat lightly and screw around, even on easy mode. So get ready to time your blocks right and avoid damage as much as possible. Some enemies telegraph their attacks obviously, and some others fake you out so hard it makes you want to facepalm. They then get a free shot at you after you've wasted your block, which by the way isn't constant like say Oblivion or Skyrim. Why not make the blocking constant? And reward the player by only stunning the enemy if you block right before their attack strikes you.Also every now and then you have to gather evidence by using your fancy FBI tools and camera. I guess thats pretty cool, it does suck though at certain parts where there are enemies, making you vulnerable because to do ANY attack, you have to put your tool away, which takes about a second and a half and then slowly pull your weapon out and then finally be able to attack. Rinse and repeat about 10 times.One of my biggest complaints with this game is how ABSURDLY slow your character moves. And "sprinting" is barely faster than how a normal person would run. Especially going down and up stairs and ramps, it makes snails look like Speed Racer. I guess you could argue he's carrying a lot of tools in his bag but even then the speed at which he moves, even when sprinting, is RIDICULOUSLY SLOW!Overall, the game is pretty decent but it could of done a bunch of things better and made the experience more satisfying with a little more effort.

content:
ry 25
												This game still holds up as a horror survival game, but the most horrifying part of this game is climbing stairs.This is a port of the xbox360 version and as with many xbox to PC ports there are issues; one of which being the aforementioned stairs issue. When trying to climb stairs (or any slight incline or decline for that matter) the players movement speed will be reduced to the point that I fear stairs in this game more than the actual horror aspect; and trust me; there are a lot of stairs. You might be thinking this is a minor issue; but not so much when you have enemies chasing you and (I am guessing) almost impossible to beat on harder difficulties.Other issues include a common issue with chapter 9 the next area wont open unless you pick up the correct weapon and then drop it. Physics when killing enemies are flawed in the sense that they bounce or fly off in an over exagerated typical ragdoll fashion. This happens a lot of the time when landing a killing blow or always when landing an execution moves. I also saw lighting issues but I didn't tinker with any of the lighting settings.On a more positive note. This game has some re-play value with collectibles and "achievements"(These achievements are simply left in the game from the 360 version and do not link with steam). As for the Story; you are a detective that gets framed then leading to you trying to prove your innocence whilst having to deal with psychotic enemies and at times; slight paranormal overtones. You will also get a choice of melee weapons that can be found almost anywhere from pipes on the wall to a shovel in the shed as well as firearms including pistols, shotguns, rifles and sub machine guns. You will also get a trusty taser but beware the cool-down time. Overall you could probably get around 6 hours of gameplay on the easiest difficulty and whilst the PC version is very buggy I do still recommend this game but I would also recommend getting it on the xbox360; after the painful amount of stair climbing I had to boot my 360 copy and no such issues were present. If you have no option but to get it on PC; it is still a decent game with a reasonable storyline just be aware that such issues as mentioned above were found.

content:
r 20, 2013
												Condemned is the sister game of F.E.A.R. developed around the same time for the same engine and platforms. However while F.E.A.R was a game of excess. Condemned was a game of subtlty. In Condemned you play as a framed forensics officer who attempts to clear his name by chasing the real criminal, a serial killer. You follow in his footsteps as you examine the victims in a really nicely designed forensics minigame. Not only that but you must fight with the residents in the city you live in.Gradually it becomes more apparent that the world you live in is going mad. You go from subways, to libraries to eventually abandoned department stores and fight mannequins. The game also does not have a focus on firearms. You only very rarely get firearms and instead use improvised melee weapons to face your opponents.Condemned is a very rare kind of game in a sea of first person shooters. One that understands how to properly scare you and delivers an engaging story and cast of characters.

content:
2, 2014
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a highly atmospheric detective-horror-shooter done from First Person view. The game covers it's bases in the melee department, with each weapon that you are able to pick up or switch with abundance (pipes, boards, fire axes, etc.) coming with its own set of combat statistics. If you are looking for a shooter, though, you might not enjoy the gameplay as each time you pick up a gun, you get the bullets in that specific gun, and are unable to consolidate ammo between guns. This tends to make melee combat your mainstay in C:CO.Being vage as to not give anything away, I can say that the story really pulled me in. Not because the main character was well-played or relatable, but because the game's environment--as previously stated--is highly atmospheric. You'll get a lot of jumping-in-your-seat moments as you play through the campaign.Overall, I give this game a 4/5, losing a half star each for somewhat linear combat at times, as well as the odd inability to pick up multiple clips of amunition for the same weapon. Everything else is pretty stellar.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												I give it 3 out of 5 stars (ie about average). Fairly short and very linear (I played start to finish in one long sitting). The ambience is nice, but there are a lot of frustrating aspects. You can only run for about 5 seconds, and even then its very slow. Worse is the fact you can only carry one weapon at a time, and you can't "combine" ammo for the same type of fire arm, so you will have to back track if you want to use those 2 or 3 bullets. Not that you need to use firearms at all, you should really learn to use melee weapons... because at the end it is mandatory (and they take away your taser too, so don't rely on that as a crutch too much). But even if you do forgo guns for melee, you will still have to backtrack a lot because you will need different melee wepons to open different doors. So slow movement + lots of mandatory backtracking. Finally many doors lock behind you for no reason (in game anyway), very often right after you pass first aid kits. So you end up feeling cheated there too. The fighting mechanics are usually ok, but there are issues. Enemies sometimes would shoot me through walls, including once through a ten foot thick concrete subway pillar. On the other hand if an enemy is crouching behind a knee high box, with their whole upper body exposed, my shots would (to their head) would have no effect - you have to wait till they come out of cover to shoot you. Enemy melee attacks for the most part can not be sidestepped; overhead smashes will auto-track you mid-swing. Also very often the range on enemy melee attacks is far greater then it should be. They would appear to miss me by about 5-10 feet, but I would still get hit. You are just expected to parry everything.By the end I felt like I has earned a blackbelt in Condemned-jutsu, the last level really forces you to master it to get by. The final boss fight though ends up being a little anticlimactic, as there are so many health kits around, you can almost ignore his hits and just keep whacking him. This became a problem at one point, because if you don't know what to do, you can whack him for ever and he will not die - you have to get him winded then press 1 (something I had never before had to do to win). If you ignore it and keep attacking, he will try to fight you some more. This almost became an infitnite loop for me.

content:
r 21, 2016
												Finally after several years I decided to try Condemned out on PC, I remember seeing footage of it years ago and being impressed with the combat, but never really picked it up on xbox. **Couple things to point out right away in case you are having some issues with the game, there is an issue with stuttering and performance with some Logitech mice, but a simple single directX file can fix it if you search online. Ran really well on my windows 10 system after that, except when I try to quit the game it will force a black screen and a need to reset the whole computer.** Without going over any key story or any spoilers:Positives: Creepy atmosphereSolid jump scares that actually got me pretty badInteresting story elements that progress in an unexpected wayVisuals still hold up on highest settingsLighter collecting aspects(only used to unlock concept art which is a plus)Combat is balanced and I never ran into extremely difficult or overwhelming sections.Detective work was really cool, use of ultraviolet light should be in more games!Negatives:Your character has the lungs of an 80 year old asthmatic whilst sprintingYou walk up stairs like an 80 year old asthmaticThere isn't really any progression for your character, you never get more health or staminaBlocking doesn't always seem to work with weapons, strafing and flailing works bestStory can be rather thin at parts, I wish they went further into some of the world building which had interesting potential.Campaign was rather short, only took me 5 hours to beat it on normal difficulty.Overall, I would recommend Condemned: Criminal Origins, I believe I picked it up in an earlier humble bundle so you can always wait until a sale and give it a try if you enjoy first person horror games.

content:
30, 2016
												This game is a coursebook for aspiring game developers on how to properly make scary games with style. Meticulous level design, astonishing work on sound and light (now THAT's what the word 'cinematographic' truly means) and NEVER a cheap thrill. It spooks you with minute details, it scares you with small stuff, it gets under your brain. An absolutely rad  and innovative game, which many other games subsequently borrowed from (but nobody quite achieved the same effect). The BEST melee fights I've ever known in a game, period.And guess what, it doesn't look dated in 2016. I dunno how Monolith did that, but it looks as cool and chillingly spooky as in 2006.In my opinion, Condemned 1 and 2 are the most awesome horror game franchise in history. Many gamers hold a serious grudge against those nasty people at SEGA who pulled the plug on PC port of the Condemned 2 (the game I actually bought PS3 for).Condemned 2 MUST BE RELEASED ON PC.

												It's an interesting old title. Definitely not Outlast or Silent Hill, but it's worth a shot.+ Nice atmosphere: Creepy and tense.+ Enemy presence: Enemies move in scary ways, they creep around you in the shadows, making noise and messing with you. They don't just rush into your face, they actually creep you out.+ Balanced combat: The combat is functional enough to help you and crap enough to keep you scared.+ The best jumpscares: Few but effective. That's the best way to do jumpscares.- Simple plot: I found the story too simple and the twist too meh for a horror game.- Short AF: I beat it in a seating and a half (~6H) and it was my first playthrough.It isn't even close to winning any kind of award, but it's not a complete waste of your time. If you like horror games, Condemned isn't gonna make you change your underwear every 5 minutes, but it's worth a try. It's nice.Simolius - November 2016

												Pretty cool game. I had not played this until now (2016). I didn't know it was on PC as well. I got this game for free with some promotion from some website I can't remember. I had tried the Condemned 2 demo on PS3 and I remembered it was quite cool and never played the whole game because I never played the first one....so here I am. The game is fairly short (6 hours or a little more if you are a completionist) and is very concentrated and immersive. Combat feels ok but of course a bit outdated (especially after great melee combat games like Mirror's Edge and Dying Light), still fun though. Graphics: it is a 10 year old game, yet it didn't disturb me graphically, it is very ok, you could even play in ultrawide, surround screens, or UHD resolutions if you wanted.Make sure you google for the 'dinput8.dll' which will fix the framerate on systems with Logitech devices (your framerate will be stuck at 6 fps otherwise). There is also a FOV fix to make the game work in ultrawide and multiscreen setups.I enjoyed it quite a lot and now I wish the second were on steam as well. I don't think this game is a masterpiece from the past, but if you never played it it surely deserves a playthrough.

												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first person horror game, developed by Monolith, famous for the FEAR series.The game places you in the slow, clunky shoes of Agent Ethan Thomas, tasked with chasing down a mysterious killer. Rampant violence and insanity is flooding the city streets, driving the population of homeless people and vagrants to attack everyone and everything. Blood, psychosis, and brutal beatdowns await you within.The game has excellent atmosphere and sound design, and despite the rather aged visuals, is still capable of producing some legitimately creepy enviroments. The gameplay involves melee combat, guns, investigations, and simple puzzle solving. Unfortunately, the puzzles and investigations aspects, while interesting, lack variety or real depth, but serve as a nice break from the combat.A little rough around the edge, the game is still worth atleast ten dollars.7.5/10

er 30, 2013
												I originally played this game on the 360 before its PC release. I freely admit that I haven't played it thoroughly since I purchased it during the Halloween 2013 sale.The actual game is fantastic. The gameplay is fairly unique, the graphics are acceptable for the era it came from, and the story/writing isn't too terribly appalling.It is worth mentioning however that the game presents a lot of problems on my modern PC. Randomly dropping to 5fps after certain cutscenes, sudden crashes, things like that.I also recognize now that the gameplay is, while enjoyable, quite clunky at times. The way the player moves feels a bit off compared to most FPS games, and the weapons ranges don't always seem to match their appearance. Neither do the enemy attacks, for that matter. Additionally, the voiceacting and dialog are both terrible, which creates a sort of harmonic resonance that serves to make both even more grating. You know the way that the smell/sight of vomit or rotting eggs has a tendency to make a person want to throw up? Well, imagine if someone ate whole rotten eggs (shells still on) and then threw them up in some kind of frenzy of blood-filled chunks and nasty egg yolks  -- it would be far more off-putting than either individual gross-out.Still, it's an enjoyable game, and well worth it if you can get it cheap.Recommended to anyone who likes something different from the usual, with the caveat that the performance might be a bit sketchy, and the polish is far from what we'd expect in a more recent game.

												So, this is one of those games that i played on Xbox 360 before i knew how to build my own PC, I was either 17 or just turning 18.. Blah blah enough with my life story.. It does look way better than the 360 version, so if you haven't seen that version... I'm sure you can imagine. This still does come from the time where the skin and hair texures are combined. So, the default KB&M controls aren't overly complicated like in some Sega games which is a good thing even if for some reason you prefer using a controller. I will recommend this game(it is free at the make war not love website at the moment) Some people have said that playing this game for extended periods of time have made them feel sick. I didn't notice that too much but I'll put that out there for anyone considering this game just in case. The gameplay is fun, even though it starts feeling like you're just doing the same thing over and over after a while..

content:
9, 2014
												Week Long Deal! Only 2,50 EUR for this masterpiece! It would be a sin not to pick this one up till the offer lasts.I did not know Monolith did not become defunct but was acquired by Warner Bros. I thought they'd really stopped developing video games for good. This all happened around the time they came out with Condemned. It was interesting to play this game after FEAR which was action-packed and you needed to quickly react and shoot enemies - at the same time the bullet time concept made it all easier. So, when Condemned came out and I saw this game did not really have any weapons in it I took a step back. I mean, melee can certainly be interesting but FPS games were never about close combat but by utilising a certain assortment of ranged weaponry. Yet, Monolith managed to make the game interesting till the very end by incorporating an exciting and mysterious storyline.You play an FBI agent who becomes a fugitive after a killer frames him for the murder of a police officer. Thomas, while hiding from the cops, tries to uncover the truth and visit long abandoned (condemned) buildings to find clues as to who this mysterious Serial Killer X might be. Throughout the game you can grab almost any object you come across. Steel pipes, planks, crowbar and even a fire axe is at your disposal to get rid of your enemies. These are not necessarily people you are after, but people who occupy these buildings - petty criminals or junkies just seconds away from a lethal overdose.Occasionally, the game lets you do some crime scene investigations. This happens when Thomas reaches a new milestone in his investigation: you have a variety of gadgets at your disposal with which you can collect samples and send them to your lab analyst - the only person who trusts you - for further analysis. That is how you can progress and go through warehouses, an old school, a library or the deadly sewers and eventually you'll reach an orchard to finally face the antagonist of the game.Condemned has an appalling story and makes you stuck in your chair until you complete the story and find out the fate of agent Thomas. It has a creepy atmosphere and it truly is a psychological horror. I do not know exactly how many such games are out there for the PC but this is certainly one of the classics.Once you pick this up and complete it you'll find out why I hate the developers for never releasing the sequel on PC.

content:
y 9, 2016
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a story about the least athletic man in existence. You play a disgraced FBI agent, a man who the story tells us has almost abnormally high muscle and bone density, but who in the game is uncapable of walking over knee high fences or running more than a few seconds without needing half a minute to catch his breath. From this, an entire game is born.The game is a horror title, with the gameplay built around exploring abandoned facilities in a city gripped by madness. Deranged citizens constantly attack you as you explore, and very little of the combat is performed with guns. Almost everything is done with melee weapons taken from objects lying around. There is a satisfying clunkiness to the combat, but its simplicity lacks depth, and there's little else meaningful to take its places, The melee weapons also take the place that keys and keycards would in other games- a sledgehammer is needed to open some doors, a crowbar others, etc. This becomes contrived when the obstacles to get past are something like a piano blocking a stairway. In this world, no one is capable of climbing or jumping. In some of the later levels there are genuine chills to be found, but the gamplay feels rote most of the time. The pace is glacial, and for most of the game you are stuck exploring these places at a slow walking pace. Whenever a story sequence takes places, you are confined to a tiny area, unable to walk ahead. There are quite a number of moments, none of which are interesting, and the wait to continue the level can be agonizing.The story is preposterous, almost farcical, with motivations that make zero sense and a clueless protagonist. There's a major disconnnect between the protagonist's motivations and the actions the player takes.  It's hard to care about catching a serial killer who kills other serial killers in a game where the primary mechanics consist of the player killing hundreds of homeless people.I'm surprised the title took less than 6 hours. It felt like so much more. People interested in this game can walk-very slowly- away.

												I tried to finish this game. I really did. But the repetitive combat and awful, boring boss encounter in Chapter 8 broke my spirit and left me a shattered man. Unfortunately, the game just didn't age well, but at least it isn't the second one. Some of the characters look so big and round as if they were carved from giant blocks of meat.Ammo is extremely scarce, which means the combat relies mostly on melee weapons. The melee weapons didn't act differently from each other in interesting ways. At least the taser and kick helped to mixed things up, but couldn't keep combat from feeling like a chore. I grew bored of it and combat takes up a huge portion of the game.At one point, I encountered a section in Chapter 8 where enemies would keep spawning until the last one with the item I needed finally came in the house for me to kill. I had to repeat myself a couple times which caused my eyes to glaze over. I nearly passed on to the spirit realm. Enemies that seemed to hit me from much further than they should did not help the combat situation either. You can't hit me with a short pipe from five feet away.The investigation aspect also falls victim to the repetition. It's great the first couple of times, but then it loses its luster and only served to move the story forward instead of being interesting. It's a fairly linear game. I did not have to rely on the light tool to follow a trail of blood. I could just press forward and hit those progression points. They had some great uses of the tools later on in the game to keep the investigating aspect from becoming dull. I just wish they could have kept the quality bar high up the whole time.The story seemed interesting and I really liked the concept of Serial Killer X. That's a neat villain to have. I'm not very sure of the supernatural aspects. They could've stayed grounded, but I suppose they needed their explanations for why an FBI agent killed over 150 homeless people, drug addicts, and others with pipes and axes and stuff. Oh well.I can't recommend this title. It's not 2005/2006 anymore.
