content:
24
												Condemned is a story-driven detective thriller with supernatural horror elements. You are Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent investigating on a serial killer called the Match Maker. Story is pretty standard, but the voice acting is good and characters are interesting, if you're into that.The game alternates between Batman Arkham-esque sections where you use gadgets to analyze crime scenes and find clues, and other, more FPS-oriented sequences where you will fight all sorts of weirdos. Combat is reminiscent of Bioshock, with its improvised weapons (among other things a paper cutter, locker door and mannequin arm) and scarce firearms, which you can never find ammo for. You are stuck with whatever they contain. Some weapons also double as key items, using for instance a fire axe to break down a door or a sledgehammer to smash a padlock. Since you can only carry a weapon at a time, this creates an economy of weapons that is pretty unique. There will be some backtracking to access some areas, some of which are secret areas with collectibles.Combat is clunky. Hit detection is horrible: you can rarely guess a weapon's range. It seems rigged in favor of enemies. There is a taser that you can use as a last resort weapons that is slow to charge back, but can be used as a last ditch effort, I guess. Combat is basically melee 80% of the time (like I said, firearms are scarce), so get used to the dance of blocking, then landing a strike. Also, enemies have different patterns. When you do find the occasional shotgun or revolver, then the game falls into faceroll territory... for however many bullets you have. 4? 5? Sometimes less.That said, the game does have a unique charm to it, plot twists are cool. I found myself not to be remotely scared even once, which was a bit of a letdown, but there are a few jumpscares. At about 7 hours, the game never overstays its welcome despite its few flaws, and has merit that makes it worth the one sitting you're going to need to clear it. Get it when it's on sale and it's a solid purchase.

												★★★★★★★★☆☆ 8/10	Condemned is a truly fantastic game back in its time and still a great game today 10 years later, it's a bit nostalgic. This game was released back when I was a junior in high school, I remember my girlfriend would watch me play it just because we'd have fun laughing at the jump scares. I used to go out and rent it all the time and eventually I traded in a couple of my games just so I could own a copy. I'm not going to go through the pros and cons specifically I'm just going to say if you like jump scares and a decent story, for 14.95 you really can't go wrong.   Another point I'd like to add is after the release of condemned 2, sales weren't strong enough to ever come back with a condemned 3. Jace Hall the creator who owns the rights, from the last I heard he wasn't sure where to go with it and he's looking to grant someone the license to continue the series and by the looks of it PC was on the list. All I'm saying is supporting this game and picking up a copy couldn't hurt. It will only help in furthering the future in seeing another condemned project.So all of you indie devs, step your game up and grab ahold of condemned and give it the revival it needs. Here's what he stated in his original facebook post in January 2015.   "Deep thought..and question...I helped to create a video game console franchise called "Condemned." I currently own the entire franchise.There have been 2 game titles released for the franchise, "Condemned: Criminal Origins" and "Condemned: Bloodshot" - they both did well, and I am consistently asked when a third game might be created.Since I am focused on other things, and will be for quite some time, this franchise is just sitting there.I am contemplating finding an interested and proven Indie development team AND PROVIDING IT TO THEM, so that they can take over the franchise and move it forward.As an indie, it can be very hard to get marketing/media attention for a title that you work on. This franchise is already quite known, has market demand, and is in an innovative genre/category.Should I explore this idea further? What say you all?"

content:
2, 2016
												Well, it's definitely something else. Think of this as less of a conventional shooter and more of a "I-forgot-my-ammo-at-home-I'm-gonna-use-this-stick-to-beat-up-enraged-homeless-people-on-the-subway-survival-horror" type of game, with a little sprinkle of detective work elements thrown in there for good measure.GOOD+ Offers more of the dark gritty atmosphere and psychological horror elements Monolith had previously showcased with FEAR+ Interesting gameplay (for the most part) - combat is based on a simple but effective melee system (strike, parry, strike) while guns are fairly sporadic and limited in usefulness+ Some genuinely unique and interesting set piecesBAD- Story is a hamfisted mess of a thing that mixes B-movie plots and horror elements, narrated by Greg Bunberg for some reason- Throughout the game, movement feels unnaturally slow and clunky - pace is grueling slow even when sprinting, you can't jump or crouch, and trivial little things that go as high up as up to your knee block your path and box you into the route the developers intended for you. (As far as movement goes, it feels like a bad console port - which it is)- Some of that clunckyness has also seeped into the combat mechanics as well - attacks don't register properly sometimes, movement is unaturally hindered- Gameplay can get really old, really fast - The monotonous gameplay is mostly broken up by occasional difficulty spikes- Cluncky, unpredictable combat + horrible checkpoint save system = some downright rage quit educing moments- Core gameplay ludonarrative dissonance - you're basically a top FBI investigator looking to clear your name by bashing the heads of a few hundred addicts, psychopaths and evil hallucinations- Jupiter Ex engine still has some nice visuals going for it (even after a decade), but this build of the engine is pretty badly optimized - expect glitches and frame rate issues even on modern machinesFor the most part, this game is an interesting counterpart to FEAR - a lot less action, gameplay and replay-ability, but more... experimentation I guess (with mixed results). If you've liked FEAR and you can endure an interesting (but aggravating) combat system and the B-movie premise, you definitely should check this one out.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a first person survival horror game that tells the story of Ethan Thomas, an FBI agent framed for the murder of two police officers, who is now on the run to find the real murderer and uncover the reason for the suddenly increased violence in the city.Being developed by Monolith Productions and released shortly after the original F.E.A.R., you will notice a a lot of parallels between those two games in terms of story telling, visual style, atmosphere, lighting effects and so on, which, gameplay-wise, makes Condemnd a better 'sequel' to F.E.A.R. than F.E.A.R. 2 was.The story itself isn't exactly mind-blowing, but it keeps you going and the more you get to know about the happenings in the city and the identity of the serial killer, the more it all makes sense.As the game was originally developed for the XBox360, the controls are fairly basic stuff for a first person game. The only thing I kind of disliked is the lack of ability to jump in the game. It's not a deal breaker, but it definitely limits the freedom of movement as you always have to find a staircase, a ramp or similar to get to slightly higher places.While the game *is* first person and you *do* get to find weapons to shoot with, I won't go as far and call it a first person shooter because the action is clearly designed around melee combat. You will find projectile weapons like pistols, shotguns etc. throughout the game, but they are rather rare and mostly only contain a few bullets. If the magazine is empty, you can't reload the gun and will have to use it as a melee weapon instead. Most of the time you will be searching the enviroment for other melee weapons like pipes, desk drawers, fire axes, sledge hammers, wood planks and so on. They all have unique stats in terms of damage, speed, range and block, so you might want to try them all out instead of sticking to one type of weapon.Since you are a FBI agent, you also get to use a couple tech gadgets to analyze blood stains, finger prints, DNA trails and so on. At various key points in the game, the HUD will tell you to use the gear, so you will have to search a room or an entire area for evidence. It's a neat little addition and adds a welcome change to the otherwise entirely puzzle-free gameplay.Graphics-wise, the game doesn't provide you with too many options and, like many console games, suffers from low-resolution textures. The atmospheric lighting manages to cover that up for the most part, but in brighter areas it gets quite obvious. Then again, the game was released in 2005 and considering there are games released in 2010 and earlier that look worse, one can hardly complain here.One of the slightly more outstanding aspects of the game is the enemy AI. You will find the enemies run away from you and hide behind corners when you aim your flashlight at them, they will wait out for the right moment to flank you, eventually will beat up other thugs if they stand between them and you and so on. The AI is not that extremely complex, but then again, a lot of recent cover-based third person shooters don't manage to do that.While the campaign felt relatively long, it only took me roughly 6 hours to beat. There are no additional game modes or a multiplayer mode, so once you are done with the story, you can either re-play it or simply move on as, apart from finding all collectible items, there's nothing else to do in the game.So, if you liked the original F.E.A.R. and want to play a game with the same unique style, make sure to give Condemned: Criminal Origins a shot as this is the closest to F.E.A.R. you can get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
29, 2016
Condemned: Fifty pounds of wet-hot trash adorned with jars of ♥♥♥♥ and feces in a melted garbage bag chucked through your bedroom window at 5AM on a SundayImagine someone desperately flailing a metal pipe they just tore out of a wall to slap the life out of a hulkish, screaming shadow that just collapsed out of the floor above. Now imagine that you are peering out the skull of this pipe swinger, close enough to this decidedly unhappy individual coming at you can practically smell the week old sweat that's coated over them. A chopper's spotlight sneaks through the tangled threads of torn wood where this stinky man who is now fighting you crash landed giving you a glimpse of their incredibly unshaven, missing tooth mouthed, seven XXXL winter coat (sautéd in blood and vomit) wearing body.First person is what I'm getting at. It's unpleasant. Condemned is a game in which you must kill or be killed. This is worth saying twice. There are four people in the game who won't try to kill you, and one of them eventually can't help but drop the business end of a shovel over your dome (two of them also die within the first 10 minutes, which leaves one). Every other person you come across just has this INVIGORATING URGE to beat you to a jello pulp. They'll wait around corners, inside vents, in a playground, you name it: there's an angry man or woman usually with a blunt object or bullet blaster ready to bruise you there.Condemned is charmingly direct. The visually palpable foul stench directing you to a hairy mass in a brown trench sitting on a train station bench accumulating a filthy camouflage, motionless, a single purpose: to have one pass by so that it may wrap its crusted appendages around their neck. The store display mannequin coming alive in an unwanted instance, strutting right through its glass display case just to slap the loose arm of one of another of its kind against your face. It's always the same. You don't have to sit and mull over the morality in question during all this. You won't have the time to, but more importantly-- you won't want to. See, there's nothing to empathize with in your foes, other than their rudimentary special resemblance (even that of which is vague at times). No, this is deliberately meant to be a violent affair. Hit these people harder than they can hit you until they can hit you no more.There is in fact a story lying at the bottom of all this physicality. You assume the role of Terry "Bulk" Meatloaf, a detective who also happens to dabble with the idea of being a copper (though the only peace keeping equipment you have access to is a taser with the voltage knocked up to 'well-done'). Also at your disposal are several forensic tools which you will use to collect evidence on the serial killer you're after. These CSI-esque segments are very simplistic, but implemented sparsely enough that they make for a nice distraction when they show up. Oh, and you're not just a regular cop, you're a supercop...your mysterious past has given you strong intuition skills and enlarged your muscle mass to a freakish degree.The plot's got this whole 'PS2-game-tranformed-into-a-made-for-SyFy-movie-upscaled-onto-2005-video-game-hardware' feel going for it. The only dialogue that'll stick is the bleeding pain blather emanating from your foes as they are felled. By the conclusion you'll be facing off against a Hellraiser kendo stick twirling ninja demon in a barnyard. Who cares! This is about being strapped to a chair in an echo chamber and getting rocked with the sounds of objects forcefully displacing viscera. Just kick back, become one with it.Before you know it the white flash riddled credits will be abusing your eyes. You'll try to come to grips with it all, wondering if there was anything left for you to think over. There's nothing, of course. Hours will pass and you'll forget ever having played Condemned. Days later its very existence will fade from your memory. Condemned is the pleasant warmth you'd feel while perched over a fizzling dumpster fire.

												This is yet another game that is good but a few steps away from greatness. As a game for a buck though, it was well worth it, even if it was a bit too short for my likings, only 5 hours. Remember, it was made by some of the same people who made fear and that work shows. The game has a great scary atmosphere that can turn even the smallest thing scary. Yet the game doesn't have an Alma character or jump scares so it doesn't go overboard. The fighting system is unique and I give it credit for that. Instead of reloading, you can only check the ammo in your gun and the game has a great system for melee weapons. The investigative tools are interesting but they just pause the game and aren't overly important in my book. The story is good, nothing special but good. My only complaint about the story is that it has an open ending but the sequel never reached PC. This all would have made this a great game except for one short coming, your character is slow. Your character moves at a very leisurely pace and even the running doesn't make you speed up that much. Going down stairs or even ramps is a huge pain because it takes forever. The point of games like Outlast or Amnesia is that you can run away from danger whereas in this game you can slowly walk away. Yes, it gives the game a steady pace but that pace is Slow. If the game wasn't so fricken slow, it would be a much better game, that and being longer. Still, it’s a great game for a dollar and I think everyone would enjoy it for a day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												Ah, Condemned: Criminal Origins.The game looks OK, graphics are kinda in the ballpark for 2006 technology and some would argue they don't age well. The plot is a bit generic and forgettable, so don't expect a Spielberg-caliber story. Replayability isn't very good; once you're through, you've pretty much seen it all. For a long time, I found this game in a bargain bin.I'd imagine you're a little confused. If you look up, it says that I recommend this game.Those things that I griped about above are all negligible (at least for me). You don't buy this game because it doesn't look like Crysis nor do you buy it because the story will enthrall you like To The Moon. You buy this game because it will scare you. The sounds and environments alone were enough to make me contemplate turning the game off in fear before I even saw any sort of threat. Dark, derelict locations such as abandoned shopping malls, run-down subways, and remote farmhouses with an eerie soundtrack (fun fact: the soundtrack sometimes makes use of subtle shepherd's tones) drive the tense feeling of this game. When the atmosphere turns hostile and enemies rear their heads, you'll be seeing a range of things from ugly street thugs to nightmarish abominations. Great melee combat with solid controls help you wade through the horror, as firearms are a scarce commodity. You'll play most of the game weilding a pipe, electrical conduit, fire axe, or anything else that you find in the environment around you. Combat is engaging and satisfying; you'll be planning your melee strikes and kicks while blocking your enemy's attacks, sometimes executing a finishing move.I'm a big fan of this game, and how easily scared I am playing horror games I definitely got a lot more than my money's worth. If you can look past some drawbacks, this game is a great experience at an even greater value for it's price.If there were any bejeezus in my body at the beginning of this game, they were all gone by the end.

It remains my favorite first-person melee game—I can think of few games that have gotten my heart beating as fast as this game.Admittedly, there are times where it can be easy to get a little lost—I had to rely on guides to find my way through a couple of levels. If you adverse to using a guide at all, this may prevent you from enjoying the game as much as I did. However, if you are a sucker for brutal combat and insane stories (that last cut-scene sticks with me to this very day), Condemned may be just right for you.Full Disclosure: I played through the game on X360, originally. My time playing the Steam version is limited.

 Review - Condemned: Criminal Origins === Rating: 7.0 / 10 A good first person action / survival horror that will make you jump from your chair more than once. With a very well-crafted series of environments, excellent sound design, graphics style perfect for this game genre, and also challenging combat, this will surely be a title loved by any horror and action gamers alike. Not for long though.=== Pros & Cons + Pros ++ Excellent sound design provides very good immersion+ Graphics style and environments are adequate, well done and very well suited for this type of game+ Challenging combat + Good enemy AI thet will know when to attack you and when to retreat, making each enemy a real danger+ Plenty of secrets and collectibles are the joy of completitionists+ Tense and overwhelming atmosphere: it will scare the stuff out of you, especially if played at night+ Good variety of weapons, each with its own feeling in combat+ Collectibles and achievements will unlock extra stuff about the lore and story- Cons -- Poor variety of enemies: basically there is the skinny and weak one, the average one, and the big one, plus some special variants rarely to act as bosses- Storyline has its degree of mysteries which is good, but is still something that looks dragged out from a stereotyped police movie mixed with a stereotyped B-class horror movie, and has some inconsistencies and downright nonsense as you will aswell notice- Short duration: took me, at maximum difficulty and looking for most collectibles around, around 7 hours to complete the adventure- A bit too many medkits lying around in the endgame chapters, and firearms also===

content:
ry 22, 2016
												Have you ever had a nightmare where you just can't move? You move slowly as if wading through mud, can't jump over obstacles or crouch under them, while being pursued by howling madmen? This is that nighmare. I mean, christ almighty it's slow. I'm not one to normally complain about a meandering pace but this is absolutely glacial. It's very atmospheric, but it'd be more atmospheric if I didn't move like a sumo wrestler on a treadmill.That said, I can see what the appeal is - or at least, what it was back in the days - in that the game is pretty effective at scaring you and making strung-out drug addicts genuinely menacing. The melee combat is... well, it's a matter of taste. If you really get used to it it's passable and a fair bit more visceral than most games (though not as good as Zeno Clash) but it's a pretty tough learning curve to get used to. The character moves incredibly slowly even in combat.That's not the end of the problems. The game talks about achivements and how you unlock them, but doesn't actually have achivements. Good job, Sega! The collectibles are tedious to find thanks to the snail's pace you move at, and they don't actually unlock anything useful (like a speed upgrade). You can't take bullets from weapons to use them in others, even if they're the same gun, so once a gun is spent just throw it away like a cheeseburger wrapper. Your protagonist carries around a literal ton of analytic equipment but can only hold one weapon, because apparently two handguns is just over his capacity. I can't recommend it, which is frustrating, because it feels like a flawed gem. Sadly, it's more flawed than gem, at least if you're entering this without nostalgia.

												I really, really wanted to love this game. I finished it when it first came out years ago, and what's strange, I played the PC port and I experienced extreme framerate drops all the time, it was basically unplayable. Then, I upgraded my PC, and I was able to play this without a problem, no framerate drops at all.About 4 years after that or so, here I am again, trying to revisit this game after a while. And even with a better PC, I'm experiencing the same EXTREME framerate drops again, even if I'm playing with everything on low. From what I understand, this is a somewhat common problem, some people experience it and some don't. There seems to be a fix also, but I'm sick of trying to fix lazy ports all the time. The gameplay is fun, the atmosphere is creepy, and all in all, this game is excellent. But with a sloppy port like this, I'm not sure if I can fully recommend it. It seems like it works for some people and it doesn't for the rest. If you're into gambling with this sort of stuff, go ahead and buy it. If you don't, stay away from this sloppy port.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 1
												-RIG-i7 4770k, 980ti, 16gb RAM, win 7Cool game! Though it hasn't aged that well.Can definitely tell this was a Monolith joint. The inital set up and premise of the main character is VERY Point Man in F.E.A.R, and I almost wonder if this takes place in the F.E.A.R universe. It has the same grimey, dirty atmosphere that I so very much enjoyed in FEAR (mostly the original) and I mwould go so far to say - it's better in Condemned. The lighting especially is so well done and really a feat that holds up almost ELEVEN years later. God damn.The story is very interesting in the same way the original FEAR was. Crazy, insane, off the wall nonsense is happening and then it goes deeper. The lore of the series is real interesting in the way that it's just so weird and straight out of left field. I'll say it could have been a little bit better. I think Fear and FEAR 2 have held up a lot better in that respect.The character models are REAL ugly. And not in a way that's meant to fit in with the grimey art direction, they're AWFUL. The environment textures are pretty good, the lighting is great. But the models... I don't know what happened lol.The combat... is frustrating. There's a lot of different weapons, which is positive. So many times i saw an object and thought 'wonder if i ca- oh i can kill psychotic people with this. nice.' but they all play pretty much the same. There's big weapons, that have reach but slow and medium reach weapons that are generally faster. Weapons do have different basic stats but I don't find myself paying much attention to that. The melee combat is simplistic in it's design. Which is a good thing and kind of not. You either hit or parry. I could not for the life of me ever figure out how to time the parries. Now every enemy is slightly different with their attack aptterns and speeds, which is cool but it means i have a hard time teaching myself the patterns. So instead of engaging in a hit and parry, back n forth with enemies, i would hit and run backwards and then go back in for another hit once they misses with their retaliation. Which just isn't that fun and personally I found the execution moves a pain to instigate as it removed the momentum.There are guns that are sparcely found - pistol, revolver, shotgun, submachine gun. Much easier to kill enemies with the guns, as you might expect, but the shooting isn't great. I did find it kind of a neat idea that you can't pick up ammo. You use the bullets in the gun when you pick it up and then you gotta either replace it with another weapons or use the gun as a melee weapon. I think I would prefer a Resident Evil inv system or something... or at the very least a TWO weapon limit. so maybe I could carry a gun and a melee weapon. I just felt awfully restricted, which I guess is by design.I had a pretty bad bug where the lights/shadows glitched and these black bars glitched across the screen in certain areas mostly with flashing lights. I had to roll back to a TWO YEAR OLD driver to fix it. Ridiculous but apprarently this is a problem with the Litech engine that they have with many of their games.Another problem I ran into is that after playing for awhile the FPS dropped to 30fps. The fix is quite easy (google it), it's  simply downloading a file and putting it in the install folder. Other than these problems, the game ran rock solid 60fps, max settings.The game has a lot of problems. I'm sure it was a lot more profound when it originally released but a lot of it hasn't aged amazingly. However, I was compelled by the atmosphere and discovering these grizzly murders. I was incredibly driven to find out what was going to happen next in the story and I'm glad I played it. Guess it's time to track down a copy of Condemned 2 for PS3... WHY ISN'T IT ON PC????

ry 21, 2016
												Terrible. I'm surprised it's so highly rated on here. Each level consists of slowly trudging through another very beige, very linear environment. I sware my play time would have been greatly reduced had the developer chosen a walking pace beyond something of a snail, you can't jump either, except when the game tells you (climbing is the same). Combat is reduced to learning your enemies melee animations, blocking, then clubbing them over the head with the dozen or so objects your allowed to use as weapons. There are guns, which thankfully reduce the amount of time your stuck in boring melee combat, but they are few and far between, and rarely have more than a few bullets. Atmosphere, which also seems to be lauded here, is pretty much cribbed from any number of 2nd rate psychological thrillers (Se7en, Session 9, etc). Hot garbage.

content:
, 2015
												Condemned was poorly made and poorly produced. The code is not good, your character will constantly stumble, objects in melee are closer than they appear. It was produced for Xbox 360 and it shows. All the non-junkie characters are built like they eat lions.That said, Condemned is unique in the way it treats horror. Nobody does what it does. The "spooky" segments sometimes come off as F.E.A.R lite, but the way it does horror and combat shows that you CAN do a game with scary gameplay when the protagonist still has a weapon. The whole "fear of homeless" thing, while dangerously close to classism, still makes for some really effective horror. The whole tone plays like a crazy over-the-top version of Seven, which I love.They made a sequel, Condemned 2: Bloodshot. Nobody likes it (they always cite a particular element that goes over the top, like this game didn't have the most ridiculous business) but everybody remembers at least one particular scenario from it, and for that reason alone they should have ported it to PC.Total playtime: 6.5 hours.Your experience of horror gaming is not complete if you don't have this game. Buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
2
												This game is a strange one, it's not particularly remarkable in any one way. Nor is it particularly terrible in any way. It falls somewhere in between, somewhere around "average" with some very above and below average moments interspersed. Firstly, you will spend most of the game using melee combat and this is surprisingly meaty and more importantly, while nowhere near the challenge of something like dark souls, it is not so easy that it becomes boring. Just the right amount of challenging for a game which ushers you along at this pace and some of the fights are quite a bit more challenging than others.  I will say that one particular upgrade slightly trivialises certain parts of the game but it's not a HUGE issue, just something to be noted and something I actually enjoyed using.You pick weapons up from the environment in an organic way whether it be an electrical conduit, a 2 by 4 or a fire axe, there is great variety and actually do allow you to approach different enemies in different ways.There are some excellent ambient sounds particularly later in the game which really serve to get your mind thinking about the environment beyond what you can actually see at times. Along with some perfectly fitting tracks humming in the background which are somewhat reminiscient of the cry of fear OST at times though nowhere near as varied. Don't expect to be overly invested in these characters as they are relatively cookie cutter affair, not too mention the "Plot" itself is deeply haphazard in how it is presented and rarely are you given a moment to care about what's happening. It takes a while but eventually it's possible to kind of like and be intrigued by a couple ofcharacters here, if in something of a "superhero movie" type way. It's nothing impressive, thoroughly throw away fair. But sometimes entertaining in a "so bad it's good" kind of way.There is a a pervasive and somewhat cheesy charm to the whole thing and as with anything which requires a relative suspension of disbelief for maximum enjoyment (and you will have to do that quite a bit here, one character gets KO'd and immediately acts as if nothing happened to them when they wake etc), this one is best played when you are in the particular mood to do so.Between some super clunky and repetitive "this door needs a fire axe to be opened, find fire axe" moments, not being able to run up and down stairs or over dirt (SUPER annoying and utterly pointless), this is a game which can really frustrate and is absolutely best enjoyed in short bursts, perhaps a chapter at a time.There a lot of people saying the game is scary but I personally don't think it is very scary at all. It's certainly not a true "horror" game in that sense. While there are undertones which prevent the game from frightening you as much as it could though there are some legitimately tense moments. And there is one moment in particular which was excellently done, wonderful use of sound effects as a means of frightening the player and it worked! One real pro is that it picks up quite a bit towards the end (too little too late though) and the nature of the ending even made me really want to play the sequel! Though don't expect it to be particularly narratively fulfilling! There is not much replay value here and while there are collectibles, I never felt compelled to specifically locate them. This game is about  moving forward, the nature of the envoronments makes backtracking a lot less fun than in other games so I just didn't bother.Average, competent, fun, tediousBoth surprisingly bad, and surprisingly good at times. If you are looking for a cheap and solid distraction between bigger games, something quite dark much not as much as it could have been due to the cheesy undertones, something that takes you from A-B while having a bit of fun all wrapped up in a relatively impressively eerie aesthetic, I would absolutely reccomend it, otherwise, I would not. Steam doeesn't allow me to write "neutral" but that is my overall score here despite the thumbs down!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2016
												When it comes to horror in gaming, I'm gonna be honest: I find horror in gaming to be laughable to the point of not even being scary. Games like Slender, FEAR, FNaF, SCP, all they do is just make me laugh and never scream in horror. Sure, some might make me flinch a bit, but that's it. WIth that said, I had a lot of recommendations for 'Condemned: Criminal Origins' for a while now, with people saying that it's one of the best FPS and scariest games out there. Well, I'd like to know what game they were playing, cause this game is not the game they were talking about. This might be one of the worst games I've played in a long while. The horror elements are laughable to the point where they are BORING. When it comes to the much touted combat, it's lame. All you do is just left click to swing or fire your weapon, right click to block, space to kick and that's it. I dunno, I guess I'm use to more refined FPS combat in games like Zeno Clash and Mirror's Edge, but I expected a bit more when it came to this game with all the praise it got. I mostly stuck with the firearms whenever I found them or tasering the opponent, to which I found the taser can make most fights end in seconds with one well tase and one well hit with your weapon. The one good thing I will say about this game is that, well, the detective gameplay is pretty fun. Granted, it's not as involved as most games with this feature, but, nonetheless, it is fun. Now, I'm not one to harp on graphics (to me, graphics are not a selling point in a game), but WOW! Does this game look ugly! Even if I did get this on Day One, I'd probably think it's ugly! The character models are janky and not pleasing to look at (even the normal characters suffer this fate). The only other good thing I'll say is that the dialouge is well acted and fun to listen to....coming from the normal characters. The psychos dialouge are just cliched bad guys who want to bash your brains in dialogue. Out of all the games I've played, this is, hands down, one of the worst I played in a long while. Sadly, that means I can not recommend this to anyone at all. If you want a game that does first-person combat better, play either Zeno Clash games or Mirror's Edge. If you want a game that does horror good, get either the first or second F.E.A.R or Amnesia. Just avoid this game.

content:
, 2016
												This game doesn't stand the test of time, but I'm kinda surprised it was well recieved to begin with. Graphics are okay except for humans but the real problem lies in the story and mechanics. After finishing it, I still don't quite know what all the supernatural elements were about and the motivation of the enemies involved. There are a lot of junkies and random human enemies too but they don't quite have a motivation for attacking you and if they were hypnotized then that's not really explained. Nothing is in fact ever explained and the rules of world is left untouched. In terms of mechanics, the game's inability to allow the player to store a gun and bullets is a major drawback and not a creative way to create tension. It almost seems like the developers didn't know which direction to approach, a survival horror (without weapons) or a crime mystery. And while they probably meant for both, their execution was lacking. The horror was fine somtimes, in fact I had a couple of startles, but the supernatural element falters heavily.

												I feel bad giving this game a negative review, but just know that it's either it's age or a really poor PC port that is getting the negative review. I've enjoyed "Condemned: Criminal Origins" a few times over the years, a few times on the Xbox 360, and once just now on the PC. The game still has the great atmosphere I remember, but the controls (at least on PC) are incredibly messed up. Ethan can't run up the stairs, instead he sticks to a slow crawl. Getting stuck in the environment is extremely easy, and graphics have not aged well (though, for ten years old, they're not the worst). If you can, I'd recommend the Xbox version over the PC version.

content:
3, 2015
												I saw Markiplier play this a long time back, but I didn't know it was on steam. One day he mysteriously stopped his playlist on it and I was curious about the rest of the game. I finally was old enough to buy it and played it for myself.That was a big mistake.I'm the biggest p*ssy you'll probably ever know. I don't know why I willingly bought this game.GOOD:- Decent graphics for it's time.- Probably the best combat I have seen in a single game ever.- Tazer goes to Super Tazer. Prepare for 1-hit kills with SHOCKZ!- Great atmosphere.- Bunch of extras stuff. (Concept art, the such. I always liked when games did stuff like that.)- Good voice acting. I guess.MEH:- You can beat the game in 6 hours or even less. (I didn't collect the bonus stuff unless it was right in front of me, so that's my time for just going through it.)BAD:- For me: Little to no replayability. Could just be me and horror games, but there's really not much to it besides extras.- I had no ♥♥♥♥♥♥ idea what the story was AT ALL xD (You're insane? Something's... weird? The final boss was--... Unexpected. o.o)- The end of the game (Unless due to the previously stated) seems like it was thrown together just to quickly wrap up the game. The area you're in is so unlike any other in the game and I noticed the game started to look cheesier and cheesier. The final boss fight was detailed, but... The end area of the game made no sense. None. Zero. Oh, also prepare for nightmares at the very end.Overall... Yeah go ahead and get this game IF, and only IF you think you can stand thinking about nothing but it for the next week or so. That's what I kinda did anyway. Still thinking about that ending to today. Ugh. Trolldevs.

content:
, 2014
												This is one of the few "scary games" that actually managed to freak me out in places. Storywise, Condemned is a great serial killer detective mystery, and is very reminiscent of the movie Se7en. The gameplay in condemned is brilliant. You could consider it a first-person shooter, but gunplay is a minor element compared to the melee combat, which this game does better than most. The melee system lets you swing, block, and kick, and is incredibly satisfying. You can use just about anything as a weapon, and are required to use certain weapons for certain environmental taks (sledgehammers to open locks, fire-axes to break down doors), which makes you switch up your strategy. The way gunplay is handled is very interesting and well done as well. Instead of finding a bunch of random ammo just laying around everywhere like in most games (which even games claiming to be realistic tend to do), Condemned limits you to what ammo is in the guns you find, making shots a commodity. Once you run out, you either use your gun as a melee weapon, or toss it and find a different weapon, which is yet another way this game makes you switch up your strategy. This is an older game, so the textures are quite low-res, but the great art direction makes up for this and gives the game some brilliant visuals. All-in-all, I highly reccomend Condemned if you're looking for a unique and well-made first-person game.

y 27, 2015
												This underrated gem was one most people missed for the 360 at launch. This, game IS GREAT! VERY UNDERRATED!Cannot help for this game being released YEARS after the original, that the graphics aren't as sharp though, maybe it's just me, but I find the textures a bit muddy. But that shouldn't deter you from one of the horror genre's most AMAZING games! I think this is one of the only games  to give you a gun, yet STILL make you feel hopeless. It's pretty crazy, there is no reloading. just frenetically checking your gun for munitions! They do not make them like this anymore, this was a signal of a dying age of greatness. I think most of the OLDER titles are the best, most of the newer games just lack thefeeling the old ones have, and still retain. Give me The Suffering over OUTLAST any day. Speaking of which, I just bought that game. I find horror games are best. They usually can incite a feeling of desperation. Outlast does that. Onetime! The first time you play it, most games aren't even scary anymore, the heavy amounts of gore, it's just like, "wow kid, nice shock value!". I bought this to relive the original, and this has some issues, but nothing game breaking, and still retains that desperate feeling. Go ahead and buy this. This game is real nice for any horror enthusiast like me. 9/10I usually NEVER give perfect ratings, but this one is close, it just has a few issues. I mean it, if you like horror, get this.

												Condemned is a horror shooter that really emphasises on horror but is it a game you want to play ? In Condemned you play as Ethan Thomas, he is an FBI agent on the hunt for a serial killer by the name of Serial Killer X who kills serial killers the same ways they kill theyre victims. Theres only one killer left on SKX list and its a killer by the name of the torturer. So its a race who can get to The torturer first. This game is quite frankly one of the best horror games i have ever played. In the game you use melee weapons to take your enemys down raging from planks to manequin arms. The game also has weapons but be carefull since theres no ammo, once you run out of ammo you have to find a melee gun quick before the enemys get you. The game has really creepy enviroments that will keep you on the edge of youre seat. The game has some problems. Minor glitches that occur throught the game will some times make you replay the chapter but after some glitches is still a fantastic game so overall skip the lame games like Resident evil 6 and Outlast, and play a game that is frankly of the scariest game ever made i give Condemned Criminal Origins a 9.5/10

content:
r 31, 2015
												I give up. This game is essentially unplayable.What I would LIKE to do is give Condemned: Criminal Origins a lukewarm review and describe it as the underachieving lovechild of Cry of Fear and Dark Corners of the Earth. Atmospherically its a nice mix of the former's crushing depression and the latter's underscore of paranoia, but the actual story is honestly too weak to live up to it.I would LIKE to elaborate on that point, but to do that I would need to actually be able to finish the damned game to give an honest opinion. But I can't, because it's a poorly optimized mess. Putting aside the FEAR engine's issues with Logitech hardware, the game simply runs like ♥♥♥. My laptop is not a beater, it can run Metro: Last Light just fine. And yet this game, which graphically looks more on par with HL2, couldn't drop its framerate much lower without being a slideshow, and that's on minimum graphics after making sure the Logitech issue was fixed.If the game runs fine on your machine then good for you, but frankly what I have played through hasn't made a good enough impression for me to care to dig thrugh the Internet's rubbish bins looking for another fix.

content:
y 28, 2016
												"overlooked/underrated" games tend to have a significant flaw that can seperate its players, some enjoy the game while others think its terriblecondamned is one such game, its influencial (outlast takes a bit from here), has great atmosphere, some of the best enemy AI and some of the best horror levels out there. But the game is bogged down by its very slow pace, which can frustrate players that are used to faster games.you pretty much play the entire game walking, the character cant run/jog for a longer distance than a small room, you cant jump, crouch nor any movements other than attacking, blocking, walking or a short sprints. theres absolutely no platforming here, and everything happens on a horzontial plane, no  ups or downs, just left or right. (think doom)this can result to a boring and frustrating experience and can be tiresome at the 2nd half of the game, folks who are used to fast paced fps might also feel out of place as the combat relies more in timing than accuracy and reflexes. (you time your blocks and hits)if one can look past the pacing and gameplay design, theres a wonderful experience to be had, but if you cant, then it can be a very painful one.

												This game had some great ideas, but really, it just wasn't fun. I really liked the idea of a psychological l horror game based on the evil that men do, and the detective element sounded cool. Too bad it sucked ♥♥♥. The only reason I finished it was cuz' I'm OCD as ♥♥♥♥ and have to finish every game I start.Pros:*Interesting Concept for Story*Interesting choice of melee centric combat*Good sound effectsCons:*Un-skippable cutscenes*Hidden guns don't do ♥♥♥♥ (you shoot people over and over and somehow melee weapons are more effective)*Weapons that have no reach somehow have more reach in the hands of your enemies, and you will be damaged even if you clearly aren't hit in their attack animation*Poorly aged character models*Poorly integrated detective/story elements in which you must scan evidence and then talk on your phone. You can't move during these sequences and they happen often. *Not remotely scary*Poorly integrated supernatural elements that clash with initial tone*Sprinting is only slightly faster than walking*Sprint button gets stuck for some reason even when you clearly have stamina left*Tedious boss fights*You can't take ammo from one gun and transfer it to another of the same kind, so you have to back track to where you left your other gun, and as I said, sprinting doesn't really work*Unsatisfying ending*Blocking doesn't work*Blocking doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing work*WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ DOESN'T BLOCKING WORK?!?!*Because blocking doesn't work, you just end up mashing to kill enemies, and they come often.*Relies on jump scares instead of atmosphere to scare you*Environments all look the sameConclusion: The only thing that is "criminal" about this game is charing 14.95 for it. I payed three ♥♥♥♥ing bucks for it and still feel ripped off. I hear the console version is way better. I haven't played it, but if you are interested by the concept of this game, check that out instead.DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY OR TIME.

content:
ber 12, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I played it for several hours and made it through to almost the end, but a few major problems kept me from finishing it and liking it. Firstly, this is one of those "gameplay first" games where there are long stretches of walking and shooting before reaching plot points. Half Life did that and Half Life was fine. This was okay too.But there is no direction as to where your supposed to go next. I would spend up to half an hour wondering where I was supposed to go. And some areas can have such similar looking hallways and rooms that getting lost is kind of easy.I had to look up guides for the puzzles occasionally. I call them puzzles because, despite the quest hint telling me what I was supposed to be doing, I had no idea what I was doing.The combat is easy in the beginning and there are legitamately scary moments here. Legit scary moments. Then I fight a butcher lady with a cleaver that two-hit kills me and I have no bullets so I have to get close to her to melee and die repeatedly. It's the main reason I quit. I did not want ot restart the level and I could not face this "boss" nor did I want to.I looked up the ending and was srely disapointed. The plot actually does get really good and builds up with some interesting predicaments. I enjoyed it up until I looked up the ending, was disapointed. Get this on discount if you want resource scarce and good plot game. Just make sure you always have bullets in reserve. Or buthcer lady will force you to restart the level.

number of helpful: 10 of 26 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2014
												Condemned is a first-person brawler with horror-ish setting and a hint of criminal investigation mechanics. Seeing the positive reviews and the fact it was developed by the same team that created one of my favorite games of all time: FEAR, I decided to give this game a try. Unfortunately Condemned turned out to be a quite disappointing and mostly dull experience.Most of your time playing C:CO will be spent being engaged in a melee combat, so you would think developers would put extra thought into this part to make sure it is actually fun, yet it is not the case. The combat in Condemned it sluggish and clunky, to a point were it gets boring and annoying pretty fast, luckily it also doesn't require any special thought on normal difficulty. The biggest problem here is how little control you have over your swings and how slow they are - with bigger weapons you might start your attack on a completely open enemy, but then notice he takes a swing at you so much faster, so it would be better to block it - but you can't! Once the attack is in motion you have no choice but to observe it being played out, which is rather unfair considering your enemies are perfectly fine canceling their attacks (faking). Speaking of blocking, at first you might want to try and be clever about how you approach your enemies, by anticipating their attacks and blocking them (or "parrying" actually, since you can't hold the button down, you have to tap it), but you will soon find out it a very unreliable method - press the button too early or too late and your block will whiff; press at the right time, but your enemy has a bigger weapon and you will be damaged anyway. Also, your block becomes even more useless once you start encountering enemies in 2vs1 and 3vs1 situations. Add to that the fact that med-kits are quite common and it will quickly become apparent that the fastest and most reliable method is to just keep swinging till everything dies, while ignoring any damage dealt to you in the mean time. On the plus side, there are some occasional firearms here and there to make things more interesting - saving those 5 bullets (more or less) for head-shots is quite fun.If instead of fighting you are more interested in Condemned's horror setting, then you need to know it is almost exclusively based on jump-scares and doesn't really try build any kind of tension. Maybe in one or two instances the developers tried to do something original, but most of the time it comes down to something jumping in your face. It also doesn't help that everything looks so blend, so rather than being scared, you will feel turned off by the low quality of the environments and, especially, the character models. Not to mention, for some reason, few significant cut scenes have their sound effects missing.Finally, forget about doing any kind of real "investigation" - gathering evidence just comes down to pressing "X" when the game tells you to. Afterward you can't really even go anywhere, as you listen to the analysis results, so in the end the whole thing is nothing more than a nuisance.Condemned: Criminal Origins might have been a decent game when it first came out, but by today's standards it unfortunately looks and feels like a budget game with almost nothing that would make it stand out of the crowd. 5/10

content:
, 2016
												Wasted all of my bullets in the first level, bad guy steals my gun and threatens to kill me with it. Proceeds to kill both of my partners with my 0 bullet gun. Actually, it seems that many of the homeless drug addicts you kill in this game have the ability to literally sweat bullets and proceed to use them to kill you, since while the shotgun I retrieved from a locked safe only had 3 bullets in it, the hobo around the corner had at least 15 rounds for his shotgun. I guess having strong enemies, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanics, and dark lit maps counts is all it takes to count as a horror game.I know I've only played an hour, and maybe it gets decent further on, but I didn't enjoy a single moment of the time I played. For a game that revolves around investigating and fighting, it's got some of the worst mechanics for both. All of the enemies I've fought so far have been actual drug addicted homeless guys that really have it out for me for no other reason than they're addicts. The melee combat is terrible. Your attacks are either too slow to attack consecutively or aren't strong enough to stun enemies. There's a 100% damage block you can use, but it's very hard to predict when they'll attack, as their recoil animations and their attack animations are nearly identical. Gunplay is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. You're only ever going to find guns with enough ammo for one, maybe two kills. You're then forced to use the gun as a melee weapon, where's it's good for a hit or three before breaking and doing negligable damage. Why use the gun as a melee weapon? Because this FBI agent apparently decided to burn his weapon holster after his gun was stolen, so you have to choose between carrying a gun and carrying an actual melee weapon. As for the investigating, it's so far literally just walking around with a magic tool out until you find a glowy bit, then you take a second tool to scan it or take a picture. There's one part where you follow a trail only visible with your tool, except that it's through a linear area and the story progressed without needing to use the tool. That's it. It's not any kind of puzzle, unless you count having to look at the controls layout every so often, since they didn't bother to give you any of the keybindings in game.Another big annoyance is medkit spacing. I'll find three in one area, use one, and decide not to waste the other two, so I progress, take some damage in the next fight, but when I go back for my medkit, the previous door has been mysteriously closed forever. I suspect this has to do with the game's age, and it needing to unload the previous area in order to load the current. It's still really annoying to have to clear a whole nother area before finding another cluster of medkits. You can find some randomly hidden in closets or on desks, but in a game where one enemy can take out nearly your full health bar if you trade blows, I think carrying medkits would have been a better choice.While I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the mechanics, the sprint feature is just terrible. You get a few seconds of hardly noticable speed increase and the bar takes ages to refill, to the point you've already forgotten about sprinting by the time it's refilled. And while I'm at it, I want to talk about how stupid the game's premise is as well. Early game spoilers ahead.So, as far as I'd gotten, the main motivation for our hero, Ethan Thomas, is that the serial killer he's hunting stole his gun (again, out of bullets) and used it to kill the cops I worked with. The local police force decides it's much more likely that what actually happened is a seasoned investigator decided to out of the blue kill the officers helping him on his case. At least, that's what the mysterious weirdo who showed up in Ethan's apartment said. I'm convinced this guy was just trying to make me look even more guilty by running from the police, but I don't care to play long enough to find out.Maybe I would have enjoyed it a decade ago when it released, but compared to other games you could buy today for $15, Condemned: Criminal Origins is a waste of time and money.

content:
r 13, 2015
												If you can play Condemned 2 Blood Shot instead of this one (was only released on PS3/360) then do so. Condemned 2 has essentially everything 1 does but its a bit better in every way and somewhat less clunky and has more variety. 2 isn't a great game but both of these are diffrent and are not terrible games. Decent games atleast.The story is a bit hard to follow in both and dousn't really make alot of sense though it sets up some interesting scenarios for you to playthrough but there is so little variety in gameplay that what your doing in the first fight of the game is the same thing you do in the last essentially with the same weapons too.Elements like how to block or when to arn't telegraphed very well to the player either, you learn that axes suck at block and suck along with sledgehammers for anyhing but objective items and the 2x4 or metal pipe maybe the best weapon in the game aside from the machinegun. What kills the game for me is how you walk so slow. You can sprint a very very short distance but anytime you hit an incline or a decline whether its stairs, a wheelchair ramp, or a small pile of garbage in a hallway you start walking very slowly. I understand why they added this but in no way does it add to the game. Its a reason to not play this game alone. Its not fun to be forced to walk slowly whenever your just looking for the item or objective or at any other time. Enemies can run through these places just fine so good luck trying to get away from an enemy.The actual melee combat is alright, nothing new but still better than the Elder Scrolls game. Enemies will reach to getting hit somewhat realistically and will be staggered along with if you block they will also become staggered. The problem is no matter what weapon you use essentially the fighting is the same. Either a weapon is worthless or its one of the few great ones.  You do find some guns scattered around but your to stupid to know how to reload so ammo is bound to each guns magazine.  Some situations and enemies can be neat but for the most part the actual fighting isn't really that great especially when you have to fight an enemy with a gun. For this you really need to just taze them then take the gun. Thank goodness the tazer recovers charge over time.Since you are a cop you investigate certain crime scenes. These are just fluffer basically as you can't do them wrong. You whip out your light, find the evidence, take a picture, and move on. Really just a gate to break up the gameplay. You cannot mess these up. You are required to do one action at a time with one choice. Graphically the game is pretty good, not as good as FEAR imo but good enough especially for the time.Story is weird and confusing. Its very hard to follow and just really a background. Who really cares about it.Having played the original years back on PS3 I kept thinking to myself of diffrent areas and scenes that were obviously taken from the first game. I wouldn't say its a 1 to 1 port as they added so much and content was definetly new in 2 but they sure took alot of ideas from 1 to the point that your not missing anything by skipping to 2 unless you care about a story thats not very strong to begin with. Just read the wiki page and you should be setup for 2 if you care. I don't really feel like I gained anything out of playing this one though aside from being frustrated with it.Its alright and if you havn't played the 2nd and don't have a console it might be worth a playthrough, just don't expect much and you won't be dissappointed.

												Hmmm Im a little conflicted on this one....So if you played FEAR, this game is from the same makers and it shows.I quite like it overall, I like the characters, the voice acting, the story and especially the presentation.But my problems lie with the gameplay and unfortunatly ultimately...the story.The game is all about first person melee combat with weapons such as pipes, 2x4's, Fire Axes etc etc.Guns do show up but this is not an FPS, so ammo will not be found in the gameworld and guns only have a limited amount of ammunition so you dont use them much/often (but that makes it all the more fun when you actually get to).The melee combat is not a problem (for the most), my problem lies in the repetition of it.You basically just fight skin jobs of the same enemies, very very little variation throughout the game all the way to the end.Another part of the gameplay...is a bit of an ermm misdirection.Right at the start you come to a murder scene, you get to play CSI and find the cause of death and other clues and evidence on who did it.This is obviously really cool....but also pretty much entirely non-existent in the rest of the game.I dont know what the reason for this was but for the rest of the game its at best only: "follow a blood trail here", "photograph a footprint there".Actually investingating murderscenes is, after that first part, no longer a part of the game.This is a HUGE let down imo.Secondly, without spoiling I can say the game has a super open ending.There are a lot of unknowns building up during the game and in the end it barely explains ANY of it.(now I have the sequel which is console exclusive and ill see if the story goes on there....)Nothing more annoying then having mystery build up without a pay off at the end....So yeah, to recommend it or not hmmmm hard one honestly.In the end I found the game just alright, its not bad really, its just rather meh made more interesting because of the story that in the end goes nowhere sooooooooo yeah I guess I dont recommend it.

content:
ry 6, 2015
												I saw this on a top ten scariest games list so I decided to give it a go. Condemned: CO does have atmosphere that is immersive and mildly creepy (complemented by a gloomy soundtrack). This is the strongest aspect of the game and it is this, along with the semi-engaging story (with the hope for a satisfying ending or something that could conjure an interesting idea), that compelled to me play through to the end. After it was all over, I was ultimately dissapointed with this as a survival horror title. For one, there were no puzzles (which are a staple of the genre). Instead, you have fetch quests (i.e. find sledgehammer to break lock on door or find valve someplace to turn off steam). The fetch quests are not even difficult because the levels are fairly linear and you are not given the option to interact with many objects outside anything that can be used as a melee weapon. The enemies (maybe with the exception of the mannequins in the department store), were not disturbing at all. And this is a major complaint for a survival horror game because it, unfortantely, bogged down the dread/scare factor quite a bit. Most of the time, you'll encounter hobos running at or away from you with x melee weapon. To the game's credit, there are well executed jump-scares at times, but for the most part you see it coming (even when they are hiding behind a wall with one arm clearly hanging out). Combat system is clunky, as it should be in this type of game, but becomes repetitious after awhile. Thus, it doesn't feel clunky anymore and engagments with enemies felt more like busywork instead of terrifying encounters. The melee weapons do vary in damage and speed but the technique (block, hit, hit, repeat) remained the same. Occasionally you can find a firearm to spice things up a bit but primarily you will be using a melee weapon. When the story wrapped up, I was underwhelmed which was a shame because the set up was decent and had potential. This would've been forgivable if there were in-depth character examinations. Yes, you do learn about the characters but it's nothing extensive that makes you either connect with them or intrigues the mind. Thus, I had no desire to replay the game for the story/characters at all. If you're a fan of atmospheric games and on the fence, then I would recommend getting it on discount because, for all its faults, it does have redeeming qualties that made me (somewhat) glad I played it. It's possible that you might find the experience more terrifying than I did because, after all, horror is subjective. However, if you are looking for a game on par with something like Amnesia in terms of horror, then I'd pass this one up. 5.0/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2013
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a psychological first-person horror game that has managed to stand the test of time as well as any other title from its era. This is thanks in large part to the game's visceral combat system which focuses on melee weapons, as well as an intense atmosphere that will keep you constantly wondering what's just around the corner. This creepy atmopshere is further developed by quality level design and some good use of lighting and sound effects. Enemy AI is mostly intelligent; your psychotic opposition will sneak around quietly, strafe and block effectively, and won't just whale away on you when they see you. However, while the game holds up just fine from a gameplay and mechanics standpoint, there are some muddy textures and awkward character models that are less than appealing when compared to more modern games.If you're looking for a game that can provide some solid thrills and an immensely satisfying combat system, Condemned: Criminal Origins is as good as it gets. An underappreciated title that plays just as well today as it did 7-8 years ago.

												This was a surprisingly fun survival/horror game.  It introduces an interesting mechanic to balance guns by making you unable to hold ammo for them - the only ammo you can use for a gun is the ammo in the gun when you find it [often only 4 or less bullets].  Additionally there were quite a few serial killer MOs that were pretty interesting and it was always fun trying to track them down.  I will say that there was a pretty huge difficulty spike at the end that forced me to reduce the difficulty in order to finish the end, however.

												I like this game because it reminds of those B horror movies so bad they're good.  So, Ethan Thomas is and FBI agent in pursuit of a murder suspect.  He tells his boss on the phone that he's not crazy and not a killer, then he goes to abandoned buildings to slay several dozen civilians with a sledgehammer and a fire axe to "gather evidence" (he also rides the subway across town while covered in blood from all those people with no difficulties).  His FBI forensics contact thinks this is fine and continues to assist him.  He periodically receives phone calls from some random old man who trolls him with meaningless hints and then hangs up.  He staunchly refuses to actually work with fellow law enforcement because random old man assures him that going psycho vigilante is "the only way".  I could see this being an instant cult classic movie.

content:
ry 25, 2016
												Straight up, this is one of the scariest games you'll ever play. I don't mean to descend into hyperbole, but really scary games seem to touch me emotionally in a way that no other genre does. I played it through once when I owned it on disc and could never go back. Now I'm here again, nearly a decade later, and I'm pooping my pants all over again.If the movie Seven were a video game, this would be it. At the time, Monolith were killing it with this and F.E.A.R released in the same year, and both games do horror right, instilling a creeping sense of dread with such great level design that you never know where the bad guys are gonna come from, or when. Although whereas F.E.A.R is more an action game, every second of Condemned drips with oppressive tension and fear. The fantastic mix of sound design, restrictions to your combat abilities, and intelligent enemy AI, as well as the fact that the game is fantastic at diverting your attention and then having an enemy sneak up on you, make this an incredibly stressful and disturbing experience. THIS. GAME. WILL. CHANGE. YOU. Playing it in the dark with a pair of good headphones will be the best and worst decision of your life. Buy it now.

content:
, 2013
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a psychological first-person horror game that has managed to stand the test of time as well as any other title from its era. This is thanks in large part to the game's visceral combat system which focuses on melee weapons, as well as an intense atmosphere that will keep you constantly wondering what's just around the corner. This creepy atmopshere is further developed by quality level design and some good use of lighting and sound effects. Enemy AI is mostly intelligent; your psychotic opposition will sneak around quietly, strafe and block effectively, and won't just whale away on you when they see you. However, while the game holds up just fine from a gameplay and mechanics standpoint, there are some muddy textures and awkward character models that are less than appealing when compared to more modern games.If you're looking for a game that can provide some solid thrills and an immensely satisfying combat system, Condemned: Criminal Origins is as good as it gets. An underappreciated title that plays just as well today as it did 7-8 years ago.

content:
2, 2015
												Aged a bit but the suspense will get to you everytime. Whether that be muffled footsteps upstairs or crushing of rubble and glass behind that corner. Every sound will make you tighten your grip on the 2x4 nail or electric conduit. You can use most of the environment as an weapon. Except Bloodshot really varies what you can use better. The brawling action is addicting except for the momentary block making it difficult if you block at the wrong time. The enemies don't have attack patterns and will deceive you whenever they can. Dodging, attacking twice, hiding behind corners when you aren't looking, whatever they can do to beat you. That makes you hesitate sometimes which I love. Again Bloodshot has more random patterns whether that is a pro or a con. And finally the story is immersive but inconclusive. I like how Rosa isn't reading a book to you. Every clue leads to another piece of the story. Feels like you are doing an actual investigation. This made me spawn a bunch of theories about what happened, where they went, etc. Short summary: Immersive but inconclusive story, addicting brawling combat with varying makeshift weapons, and heart-pounding suspense. 8.7/10

content:
y 8, 2016
												I've been a fan of Condemned: Criminal Origins ever since I first got an Xbox 360, and replaying it on the PC was just as enjoyable an experience. The focus on melee and improvisational weaponry despite the game's first-person view was handled rather well, and a refreshing change from the usual shoot 'til you get more guns and become bullet Jesus fiesta.The game's backstory is also rather interesting, and does a decent job of segueing from wrongful accusation to weird mystical whatsitsfutzery without the latter feeling too much like a cop-out. Supernatural shenanigans are ramped up at a slow but steady pace, and for the most part don't trump your reliance on humany ingenuity and/or stubbornness. However, a lot of what's going on seems left unexplained unless you really go digging, so the telling of said backstory is sub-par.Your character's investagatory abilities also come into play, but my feelings on the bits where you have to use them are middling. At some points, they feel situationally appropriate, and feel rewarding once you figure out what to do and where to do it. At others, investigation seems like tedious filler that could be avoided by something more action or brute-force based. Thankfully, these bits eventually come to a complete stop, leaving you to all the beatings you desire.One thing that I particularly enjoyed in Condemned were the environments. Despite everything being fairly dark and, in most cases, run down, almost every area has a distinct feel and different reasons to feel unsettled while you traverse them. My personal favorite is the school you eventually get to, especially the bit with the swimming pool. You'll know why when you get there.Despite the game showing its age in many respects, I recommend adding Condemned: Criminal Origins to your horror library. Now if only they'd release the sequel to PC as well.

												Story: The game sets on several areas filled with questionable numbers of psychopaths that I forgot about but they see to be near each other. It's about a talented agent and investigator named Ethan Thomas chased by his former Bureau officers for the crime he didn't commit. As he tries to survive his way through a bunch of psychopaths to find the real criminal and clean his name he encounters several supernatural things. The Ending is cheeky though didn't like it.Gameplay: In this game gun ammunition is scares make your every shot count, you can't even reload. You can use different kind of weapons such as plank, pipes, fire axe, paper cutter and guns (guns are not easily found). It feels like first person Dark Souls combat wise, block and attack. The enemies AI are hard to kill because they are as strong as you especially if they are in numbers although you can't use their numbers as advantages because they hate you as much as they hate each other. They will attack their allies if they got accidently hit by their alliesThis is one of those games that makes me dizzy for a while I don’t know why.Graphics: It did not appeal to me. It looks dated. Design: don't like the character designs they look fat on those clothes. Except the guys who haunt Ethan those guys are ok.Sound and Music: The music theme didn't match the atmosphere of the game.

content:
er 19, 2015
												Let's get a few things straight.1. This is supposed to be scary.  And, yeah, it works ok.2. This is apparently supposed to be about police.  No.  It's frankly insulting to police officers.Pros: The melee combat is actually pretty awesome.  It drive you nuts at first but once you get the hange of it, it is brutal.  Unlike any other FPS that is supposed to be horror, this works really well, because your ability to fight back is... well not great.  This game is the same folks that made FEAR and you can feel some similarty, but where FEAR was rarely scary because you were the ultimate badass, in this game you will run away screaming.  I think a lot of games should copy the melee in this game.  It's clever, simple, and it works.  Just saying.  Additionally, the game is really quite creepy.  Not the storyline which is terrible, but the levels.  Very. Creepy.Cons:This game involves a guy who is supposed to be a great serial killer investigator.  But you will NEVER know why because he will spend the game being the most gullible idiot that ever tried to solve a crime.  Moreover, he will be treated like a child by everyone he works with.  They literally read things for him, because, I assume based on how he behaves, he can't read.  The evidence finding sequences are painful.  The only good thing about them is at times you are so creeped out you find yourself freaking out slightly as you do them  But they are nonsense.  Your character is a complete idiot.  Frankly, calling him an idiot is an insult to idiots.  He's an airhead.  He has no ability to think.  It's quite annoying that you can't.. move.  This is FEAR without... well any ability at all to do anything.  You can't jump or duck, except where the game invites you to.  Which is.. really weird.  Overall: A fun game.  but... could have been a lot better.

												I can't believe I didn't hear about this game until 9 years after release. The graphics are obviously a bit aged, but imo they hold up very well, unlike most titles of it's day. The combat takes some getting used to, but once you learn timing your moves it becomes a lot of fun. Especially since these enemies -will- irritate you enough that you'll want to beat them to death with a gas pipe.The storyline is quite interesting. It's like a mash-up of Silent Hill, Bioshock, and Outlast. It's got enough depth and quick shot moments that you'll want to pay attention.  My one complaint? The obvious one: No Condemned 2 for PC. Bad move considering you'll want to play the sequel immediately after this.

												A true horror classic from SEGA/Monolith.Picture this: you take a subway to the department store to grab a few things, then you head on over to the local library to check some books out.  Afterwards, you stop off at your kid's school for a PTA meeting, followed by a brief jaunt out to the countryside to eat some apples at a farm.  All the while, you get to hang out with serial killers, PCP-powered hobos and even a cenobite or two.  Yesiree, this game has it all.You don't want to miss this, so grab a copy now!!

												eeehhhh.... I actually have played more than 3 minutes that Steam has recorded because I was using the right-click context method(which sometimes Steam doesn't register - so I'm guessing this game is only using Steam as a distribution platform rather than as DRM?) to have it run on my DGPU as this game doesn't seem to be fully supported under Optimus.Now, game's a bit dated, but despite that, my Intel HD4600 was unable to play this game maxed out with all eye candy on @ 1080p60....average fps was 20 and jumps from a measly 10 to 40 at times, which is why I obviously opted to run it on my 980M.Ok, so you start the game off as some FBI agent solving a case and then suddenly someone else comes in and kills your campanians with your gun and the higher ups put the blame onto you as there was no other witnesses. So off you go - avoiding the cops to clear your name, stalking and trailing behind the person who killed the two guys that was there with you. So you find out this guy is like a serial serial killer; he kills the serial killers who kills the victims but with a twist - he makes them use their own methods of killing to kill themselves with.... so off you guy, following his trail, but always a couple or so steps behind as they're already dead when you rock up. So eventually your manage to catch up to this guy and beat some sense into him, but not before an old guy comes out and knock yo ♥♥♥ down. You wake up in some farm, get lectured by the person(not the old guy), then the old guy saves your ♥♥♥ but unfortunely took of your finger but at least you're alive. So now you go into the barn and find this mysterious dude who seems to be causing the problems. You beat his ♥♥♥ and his minions and win!
