r 31, 2015
												...Great game...1st game I ever played on the 360 in 2006. Just as good today. But here are the few frustrating game quirks you will have to deal with... The block mechanic, no matter how hard to try to master & analyse it...it will so often be your undoing, it will be your demise so often..it is a severe problem, I learned to play without it in the end...attack then back-peddle worked much better. Sprint/run can also not be trusted...it feels like and acts like there is glue on the souls of your shoes...very odd. Next, once in a while when the AI & I were using the same weapon type, my melee reach was about a 1/2 or a 1/3 of their impact range. I really noticed this is the 'Orchard' level where we all used flaming torches as melee weapons. I had to get within about 4ft for a hit to register but they could hit me between 10-12ft away...that seemed very cheap & a real cheat by the game mechanics. Finally, you will always slow down to a crawl on stairs & you will often stick on the most minor of steps...odd as steps/stairs will not slow the AI...    Other than those oddities it's well worth a play thru...a short game which took me 5hrs in total to complete....so in the end recommended :-)

2, 2015
												Aged a bit but the suspense will get to you everytime. Whether that be muffled footsteps upstairs or crushing of rubble and glass behind that corner. Every sound will make you tighten your grip on the 2x4 nail or electric conduit. You can use most of the environment as an weapon. Except Bloodshot really varies what you can use better. The brawling action is addicting except for the momentary block making it difficult if you block at the wrong time. The enemies don't have attack patterns and will deceive you whenever they can. Dodging, attacking twice, hiding behind corners when you aren't looking, whatever they can do to beat you. That makes you hesitate sometimes which I love. Again Bloodshot has more random patterns whether that is a pro or a con. And finally the story is immersive but inconclusive. I like how Rosa isn't reading a book to you. Every clue leads to another piece of the story. Feels like you are doing an actual investigation. This made me spawn a bunch of theories about what happened, where they went, etc. Short summary: Immersive but inconclusive story, addicting brawling combat with varying makeshift weapons, and heart-pounding suspense. 8.7/10

content:
er 16, 2012
												Beautifully, brilliantly grotesque. Seven years later this perfectly pulpy first-person brawler looks better than ever as the viewer descends deep into the abstract, hellish heart of human violence. In almost every respect from design to art to coding it is a well realized experience of tension, like Doom in an episode of The X-Files, in which demons called The Hate enter stealthily into a metropolis causing a plague of psychopathic madness as heralded by dead birds. The lines between reality and fantasy are so often blurred the viewer so often cannot tell if they are in the real world, hell, or if they too are touched by insanity. The combat is brutal, pipes or 2X4s torn from the wall batter opponents to mush, and exploration and investigation (though far too linear) break that up to move the narrative along. It's a grim experience to be sure but with an undeniable message: "He who fights with monsters might take care lest he thereby become a monster."

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2014
												Monolith Productions had a busy year in 2005. F.E.A.R. was a terrifyingly brilliant first-person shooter released exclusively on PC. Condemned: Criminal Origins was also released as a launch exclusive to Microsoft’s new Xbox 360. Despite the close time frames, the games differed on gameplay mechanics but both delivered on horror. F.E.A.R. played on the psychological battle in Point Man’s mind but Condemned built on the dread of the scenario. In F.E.A.R., the player felt very powerful with plentiful ammo, slow-mo abilities and resilient armour. But in Condemned, the player has to rely on whatever can be found lying around in grimy, dilapidated buildings. The feeling of vulnerability makes Condemned more of a survival horror than a straight-up horror.StoryEthan Thomas is a fairly green detective with a chequered past revolving his deceased father. Investigating a series of murders involving mannequins, Ethan is brought to an abandoned building where there is a new crime scene. Shortly after, Ethan becomes a fugitive but is still committed to investigating the case in order to clear his name. Moving from derelict buildings to deep underground tunnels, the feeling of unease is exacerbated. The enemies are mostly psychotic bums who seem to be under the influence of something (or someone). They attack Ethan with animosity maybe because of his uniform but then they attack each other as well.The story is quite light on exposition and takes some time for things to come together. But it does not impede the sense of dread in the situation.GameplayAfter losing his firearm, Ethan uses any blunt-shaped instrument that he can find. Pipes, 2x4s, sledgehammers, axes all aid Ethan in his defence. Sometimes the occasional gun can be found, usually with only 3-4 rounds of ammunition. The guns can be effective, especially when the shotgun is in close range. But it’s the melee combat that the game focuses on. Swinging sharp or blunt objects is very satisfying. The sense of weight and inertia is felt through the controls and judging the timing of the block offers a unique challenge. Larger tools such as axes and sledgehammers offer a lethargic yet heavier blow that can also break down certain doors. Although it’s odd how a door would sometimes prefer to be smashed open by a specific tool. An example is when a door requires an axe to be breached instead of a crowbar or vice versa. Strafing into a new position as the enemies swing is a better technique than blocking. Moving position causes them to miss allowing for a counter attack when they’re vulnerable. This tactic was used more than the block mechanic as Ethan doesn’t hold the blocking position and the timing can be quite unpredictable.Ethan’s taser can be used to temporarily stun enemies for a more orchestrated strike. His kick ability also helps sustain a more consistent attack during the swinging of a melee weapon. If the enemy is begging on his knees, the player can choose a finishing move such as a neck break or head butt. However, heeding the cries of the half-dead hobos will leave Ethan open to a surprise attack from them.  The other aspect of Condemned is the investigations. As Ethan was on call to a crime scene, he held onto his forensic tools. When prompted, Ethan will bring out a variety of tools specific to the evidence including a camera and a black light. His lab contact back at the station, Rosa, will instruct him on what evidence to search for and receives images from Ethan via text message. These sections are fairly scripted without the need to understand forensics. The atmosphere while investigating crime scenes is thick occasionally erupting with horror. But the slower pace differentiates from the piercing action sequences of the combat. Ethan’s torch helps navigating the darkly lit environments more easily but can alert enemies of his presence, ruining the chance of a surprise attack.Condemned: Criminal Origins is truly terrifying. Monolith knows how to make you jump out of your skin but also how to permeate fear into your psyche. The difference is fear is a layering of brooding tension, whereas a sudden shock would cause the jolt that releases a burst of adrenaline. Either way, Monolith succeeds at both. The sense of loneliness and enclosure is felt in every step, raising the heartbeat of any player. The squalid level design is quite limiting but its linearity allows Monolith to create the tense experience exactly as they want it. They sure know how a gamers’ brain works. Scare tactics are subverted and players are enticed into a seemingly predictable horror cliché before being thrown a curveball shock.TechnicalCondemned was a technical showcase for the Xbox 360. The HD graphics showed off the potential for the console. The sound of steel meeting flesh makes a squelchy thump that will equally disgust as well as satisfy. Often you’ll find yourself standing still in order to listen out for footsteps. Believing them to be your own you continue. But then it happens again. You stop. But the footsteps continue for another two steps. You are not alone. This kind of sound design perfectly compliments the already creepy atmosphere with a gloomy score underpinning the tension.VerdictThe horror…88%

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 3, 2014
												Let Monolith take you through a joyride with creepy atmosphere, scary visual effects that keep you on edge, a great story, and satisfying gameplay. Condemned Criminal Origins is a game where you play as FBI Detective Ethan Thomas who is framed by a serial killer for the deaths of his fellow officers. The only thing he can do is prove his innocence by tracking down the killer. But it's not a simple walk in the park, along the way you will fight violent civilians whose number has been growing in the city recently.The enemies themselves are so scary because they seem like regular people from far away but every time you get close to take a swing you see their messed up demonic faces. It's really cool. The enemies kind of behave how I imagine crack heads would. They usually have a melee weapon with them but they can, if forced to, grab a weapon from the map. Combat is really satisfying as you can swing, block (which causes a stun if done successfully), and kick. It's kind of like Kirby games because you can get different weapons mid-level that you choose depending on your mood (except for the scary crack heads). There are also guns in the game. Both you and the enemy can use it. The guns are more like a Get out of jail free card because it usually kills an enemy with one shot. There's also a taser but it's similar to the gun because it makes things too easy (except for one situation).The investigation scenes are also better than the ones in F.E.A.R. In F.E.A.R you are given more pieces to the puzzle of what is going on by pushing E on a computer and letting your friend talk about what you found. In this game you have to use forensic tools to find the clues rather than hit a simple button. For me it’s more satisfying to use the tools because you actually see the evidence and hear the results of its analysis.Only con of the game is that your character walks SO SLOW. His sprint is as fast as a normal walking speed but it only lasts 5 seconds. This is bad for two reasons. One there are collectable birds and metal pieces that you can find in the level. How do you expect me to explore when I am so slow. I go to a place where I think there will be a bird, there isn't, I try to run back to the path but I run out of sprint, I cry from frustration. The second reason why the running speed is bad is because some enemies (only a few each level) have guns. So you have to run towards them and take them out but you can't do that because you are so slow. The only way around it is to use a gun or the taser.Nonetheless this is a great horror game that gets under your skin rather than relies on jump scares. Definitely get it if you like F.E.A.R.

content:
ry 22, 2016
												At first sight, this may be just your average hobo killing simulator. However, it's more than that :)It's basically a horror game with melee combat, so not exactly your traditional shooter (though guns can be used in the game). It's the creepy, tense kind of horror, and while there are a few jump scares, fear comes from the tense atmosphere.It's also worth keeping in mind that this game was released about ten years ago, and it shows, especially when it comes to game design. Condemned adheres to old game design philosophies, such as slow walking speed, backstory told via loading screen and documents (which are locked behind collectables), locking areas behind doors that can be broken only after a certain weapon has been found, etc.These are not negative points; they're just part of the deal - old game, old design. But if you have patience, you'll find a wonderful game, with beautiful level design (albeit linear), wonderful melee combat and a tense horror atmosphere.The only negative is that the game doesn't really make any efforts of explaining the story, so you'll have to collect all birds and metals to get some additional documents that explain the story. But it's worth it and I can say I definitely recommend this game. It's an old gem.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2014
												Monolith Productions had a busy year in 2005. F.E.A.R. was a terrifyingly brilliant first-person shooter released exclusively on PC. Condemned: Criminal Origins was also released as a launch exclusive to Microsoft’s new Xbox 360. Despite the close time frames, the games differed on gameplay mechanics but both delivered on horror. F.E.A.R. played on the psychological battle in Point Man’s mind but Condemned built on the dread of the scenario. In F.E.A.R., the player felt very powerful with plentiful ammo, slow-mo abilities and resilient armour. But in Condemned, the player has to rely on whatever can be found lying around in grimy, dilapidated buildings. The feeling of vulnerability makes Condemned more of a survival horror than a straight-up horror.StoryEthan Thomas is a fairly green detective with a chequered past revolving his deceased father. Investigating a series of murders involving mannequins, Ethan is brought to an abandoned building where there is a new crime scene. Shortly after, Ethan becomes a fugitive but is still committed to investigating the case in order to clear his name. Moving from derelict buildings to deep underground tunnels, the feeling of unease is exacerbated. The enemies are mostly psychotic bums who seem to be under the influence of something (or someone). They attack Ethan with animosity maybe because of his uniform but then they attack each other as well.The story is quite light on exposition and takes some time for things to come together. But it does not impede the sense of dread in the situation.GameplayAfter losing his firearm, Ethan uses any blunt-shaped instrument that he can find. Pipes, 2x4s, sledgehammers, axes all aid Ethan in his defence. Sometimes the occasional gun can be found, usually with only 3-4 rounds of ammunition. The guns can be effective, especially when the shotgun is in close range. But it’s the melee combat that the game focuses on. Swinging sharp or blunt objects is very satisfying. The sense of weight and inertia is felt through the controls and judging the timing of the block offers a unique challenge. Larger tools such as axes and sledgehammers offer a lethargic yet heavier blow that can also break down certain doors. Although it’s odd how a door would sometimes prefer to be smashed open by a specific tool. An example is when a door requires an axe to be breached instead of a crowbar or vice versa. Strafing into a new position as the enemies swing is a better technique than blocking. Moving position causes them to miss allowing for a counter attack when they’re vulnerable. This tactic was used more than the block mechanic as Ethan doesn’t hold the blocking position and the timing can be quite unpredictable.Ethan’s taser can be used to temporarily stun enemies for a more orchestrated strike. His kick ability also helps sustain a more consistent attack during the swinging of a melee weapon. If the enemy is begging on his knees, the player can choose a finishing move such as a neck break or head butt. However, heeding the cries of the half-dead hobos will leave Ethan open to a surprise attack from them.  The other aspect of Condemned is the investigations. As Ethan was on call to a crime scene, he held onto his forensic tools. When prompted, Ethan will bring out a variety of tools specific to the evidence including a camera and a black light. His lab contact back at the station, Rosa, will instruct him on what evidence to search for and receives images from Ethan via text message. These sections are fairly scripted without the need to understand forensics. The atmosphere while investigating crime scenes is thick occasionally erupting with horror. But the slower pace differentiates from the piercing action sequences of the combat. Ethan’s torch helps navigating the darkly lit environments more easily but can alert enemies of his presence, ruining the chance of a surprise attack.Condemned: Criminal Origins is truly terrifying. Monolith knows how to make you jump out of your skin but also how to permeate fear into your psyche. The difference is fear is a layering of brooding tension, whereas a sudden shock would cause the jolt that releases a burst of adrenaline. Either way, Monolith succeeds at both. The sense of loneliness and enclosure is felt in every step, raising the heartbeat of any player. The squalid level design is quite limiting but its linearity allows Monolith to create the tense experience exactly as they want it. They sure know how a gamers’ brain works. Scare tactics are subverted and players are enticed into a seemingly predictable horror cliché before being thrown a curveball shock.TechnicalCondemned was a technical showcase for the Xbox 360. The HD graphics showed off the potential for the console. The sound of steel meeting flesh makes a squelchy thump that will equally disgust as well as satisfy. Often you’ll find yourself standing still in order to listen out for footsteps. Believing them to be your own you continue. But then it happens again. You stop. But the footsteps continue for another two steps. You are not alone. This kind of sound design perfectly compliments the already creepy atmosphere with a gloomy score underpinning the tension.VerdictThe horror…88%

content:
ry 25, 2016
												Straight up, this is one of the scariest games you'll ever play. I don't mean to descend into hyperbole, but really scary games seem to touch me emotionally in a way that no other genre does. I played it through once when I owned it on disc and could never go back. Now I'm here again, nearly a decade later, and I'm pooping my pants all over again.If the movie Seven were a video game, this would be it. At the time, Monolith were killing it with this and F.E.A.R released in the same year, and both games do horror right, instilling a creeping sense of dread with such great level design that you never know where the bad guys are gonna come from, or when. Although whereas F.E.A.R is more an action game, every second of Condemned drips with oppressive tension and fear. The fantastic mix of sound design, restrictions to your combat abilities, and intelligent enemy AI, as well as the fact that the game is fantastic at diverting your attention and then having an enemy sneak up on you, make this an incredibly stressful and disturbing experience. THIS. GAME. WILL. CHANGE. YOU. Playing it in the dark with a pair of good headphones will be the best and worst decision of your life. Buy it now.

content:
ry 24, 2016
												Considering that this game came out in 2005, back when "volume lighting" was new at the time. This is one of those games that tried too hard to shove in all the graphical features in over quality contents. Even Flim Grain was in it, no way to disable that without disabling the whole shader.  Those are some bad times...Onto the story telling development... The game is rated M for mature. Mainly because of the violent and gore, however... it play out as if it was directed for teenagers.  Kinda missing the whole point where your intented player/crowd target are.You start out as an FBI agent character, you're in a building with bunch of drug addicts welding nailed plank and lead pipe trying to kill you. Some how it's ok for this FBI shoot to kill in order to defend yourself.  What did I do?  I shot them in their legs.  ONLY their legs and yet they die on second shot. Because the first shot doesn't even slow them down at all.  This really goes against the principle of working for law enforcement, during an crime investigation. Seriously... what the heck? You just don't get free-passes to killing anyone. Sure, I could kick them down, but that's still missing the point here. Being an FBI isn't an expressway to license-to-kill.As for the storyline, it's very poor. Doesn't take account of important details to form its plots.  Like when you get knocked out by power fusebox.  (yeah I know... how? there are no violate materials in it.)  An main character, a serial killer, took your gun and ran.  While we were still in the game building, he pointed gun at me later on when he cought me off guard.  He was able to fire 2 bullets from that gun at someone else who tried to rescue me.  What's the problem?  I already emtpy the whole clip in that gun before he took it from me. There's no way he would've gotten another clip.As for the gameplay, It's also poor.  It's trying to be an scare-tactic walking-around-in-the-dark-building, even though it's never really dark enough to get freaked out by minor things like rats runing across the room on cue.  There was too often that these hostile NPCs running across the doorways or other end of a hallway you're in as on cue scare event. Which doesn't really feel right for any of those moments.  Because they just go hiding for a moment and then attack you, even though you could see where they were the whole time? It's awkward. Didn't even need to use my flashlight at all.This game is a flop and I'm very much surprised to see that people are still rating this positively good after all these years.  Just what the heck, people?  F.E.A.R. (the game from Sierra) came out in the same year was far better than this game when it come to AI, scare-tactic. and story development.Didn't take very long to disappoint me.

content:
2014
												tl:dr: The scariest game from the pre-Amnesia era.From the makers of FEAR comes this FPS, which is one of the scariest games I have had the fortune to play.The story starts out interesting, becomes very intriguing, and is a pretty powerful driving force for the game, though the ending could have been handled better. The gameplay has two main elements. The first is the melee combat, which is rarely - if ever - done this well in FPS games. Using planks, rods, sticks, pipes, axes and sledgehammers, you feel the crunch of every hit, as blunt (or sharp) metal goes through flesh and hits bone, with the enemies reeling back, screaming, regaining their balance, only to come lurching right back at you with a swing of their own weapon. You really feel like they want to kill  you VERY F*CKING BADLY. Their cries of anger and their great animation adds a very real intensity to these encounters, so kudos to that. And a good thing too, because I can count on one hand the number of times I had a gun.The second element is the inclusion of investigation tools you have to use at certain crime scenes. It mostly adds color to the game , because mechanically it's not very challenging. Sometimes the game had difficulty registering that I was pointing the camera at a piece of evidence because I wasn't at the right angle, which was a bit annoying. But at certain points the gameplay embraces these mechanics and turns them into gameplay. The setpiece when I had to follow a line of paint in an abandoned house, which was only visible by the light of a UV torch was one such highlight. As you can't have an investigation tool and a weapon equipped at the same time, as the line crossed the floor, walls and ceilings, the feeling of vulnerability as I went from room to room, unarmed, staring at the ceiling, while hearing the sounds of my attackers following me in the shadows was immense.To sum up, this slightly underrated crime-horror is something I definitely recommend to people who enjoy sh*tting their pants. The interesting story and the intense, atmosheric and scary gameplay add up to a great game, which as far as tension goes, was only bettered by Amnesia. Buy it.8/10

content:
8, 2014
												This is a very old game, so I'm not sure how useful this review is. I guess someone might read it, considering it's up for sale on the Steam store.Anyway. Decent game, mainly focused on melee. Graphics are very decent for the time, though you do have to jump through some hoops to make the engine actually work and give decent framerates (usually fixable by disabling HID devices in Control Panel -> System). The gameplay itself is pretty good, guns are pretty widely available so I actually used them most of the time. You are for some reason hamstrung with the limitation that you cannot carry more than 1 weapon at a time, even if it's something that you could conceivably stick in your pocket, like the .45 pistol. I guess your taser is already taking up all of your pockets. The walk speed in this game is hideously slow and the sprint meter goes down WAY too quickly, especially when you have to game the system and run back and forth killing dudes and then running back to caches of more guns (after all, our hero can't carry spare shotgun shells in his coat pocket). Sound design is pretty nice, very atmospheric and oppressive. There were a couple places where the music is too loud and jarring. The jump scares were mostly pretty predictable but thankfully there weren't too many of them.This game surprised me the most with the length. It feels longer than it really is, but I beat it first time through in 6 hours. For a game without much replay value (it's essentially a corridor with cutscenes), that's not very long. And even then, it probably felt longer because the gameplay was beginning to wear on me.I'm on the fence with this one. If it had a little more content, I might be more willing to recommend it. As it stands, though... buy it if it's 75% off or something. I would have trouble justifying paying more than 7-8 dollars for it.

content:
18, 2016
 Curator-esque Review Condemned: Criminal Origins is an excellent first person horror game from the creators of F.E.A.R. that features brutal melee combat interspersed with crime scene investigation elements.  For its age and replayability, I recommend picking it up during a sale.   Condemned: Criminal Origins Review  Story Players take on the role of Ethan Thomas, a talented FBI agent specializing in the investigation of serial crimes.  Thanks to his perceptive instincts, Thomas builds a reputation for hunting down several notorious serial killers.  His latest case involves investigating the serial killer known as the "Matchmaker".  But soon Thomas discovers he has been framed for the murder of two police officers and must use every tool he has to survive the manhunt and bring the Matchmaker case to a close. Gameplay Condemned's gameplay can be considered survival horror with an emphasis on melee combat.  While guns make an appearance, they are few in variety and ammunition.  Guns cannot be reloaded but they can drop most combatants in one or two shots depending on their lethality.  When you invevitably run out of lead, you'll have to use other means to defend yourself.  Pipes, two-by-fours, paper cutters, even locker doors can picked up from the environment to protect yourself.  Ethan can perform a low kick to create reactionary distance as well but learning when to block an attack and when to strike is important to survival.  Enemies will try to feint you into blocking as well as swing wildly when struck adding depth to combat.  Thomas also has a recharging taser he can use to stun and disarm enemies, but be warned enemies will find another weapon in the environment if you let them. The AI of enemies also allows them to hide and wait until they can jump out and hit you. As an investigative agent Thomas is known for his sharp senses.  When prompted through a visual effect, Thomas can use one of several CSI tools to analyze evidence at a crime scene and transmit it to his lab technician, Rosa, for analysis.  There are hidden collectables to find in each level as well as an endgame decision to incentivize replay if you so choose.   Design Released in 2005, Condemned certainly shows its age in terms of textures and animations at times.  Textures can be muddy and some character models appear puffy or move oddly at times.  The game's pedigree comes through in the areas of lighting and sound.  One of the best examples of Condemned's strong points is the level where Thomas finds himself in a long abandoned department store, a level so creepy that few rival it in all the games I've played.  From the enemies you fight in the level to the ambient noises you can hear, every level has its own feel to it and it's own aesthetic.  The finale to the game is quite a spectacle and will definitely test your combat skills.The only major technical problem that I encountered while playing occurred during the subway level.  For some reason almost all sound cuts out for me during this level except for a select few noises like gunshots.  This lack of sound only occurred during this one level and while it ruins the immersion in this instance, I chose to overlook it since the rest of the game was flawless technically save for a minor progression bug (solved by reloading my save).  In the event you desire to fix the sound on the subway level, there is a fix you can find in the discussion forums for the game. Final Remarks I consider this game to be some of Monolith Production's best work.  If you have a love for any of those late 90's, early 2000's crime scene investigation shows, or want an atmospheric first person psychological horror game, this is a game for you.  My advice for how to play: at night,  lights out, and headphones on.

												I like this game because it reminds of those B horror movies so bad they're good.  So, Ethan Thomas is and FBI agent in pursuit of a murder suspect.  He tells his boss on the phone that he's not crazy and not a killer, then he goes to abandoned buildings to slay several dozen civilians with a sledgehammer and a fire axe to "gather evidence" (he also rides the subway across town while covered in blood from all those people with no difficulties).  His FBI forensics contact thinks this is fine and continues to assist him.  He periodically receives phone calls from some random old man who trolls him with meaningless hints and then hangs up.  He staunchly refuses to actually work with fellow law enforcement because random old man assures him that going psycho vigilante is "the only way".  I could see this being an instant cult classic movie.

content:
ry 21, 2016
												I get really immersed and constantly yell "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" whilst beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of a guy.But in a serious review, this game is really fun. Due to being a avid horror fan it's been on my list for a long awhile now and I want to kick myself for not playing it until now. The combat is the main attraction: it is absolutely fantastic. Aside from some iffy encounters (In one fight it felt like I was playing Morrowind because nobody was hitting anyone) it was pretty satisfying.I like that sometimes enemies accidently hit each other then they start fighting. This game is one of few that I feel makes guns feel as scary and powerful as they are in real life. So unless I have one too, I'm scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ due to their long range and high damage. This is probably the only game where I counted not only my shots as I fired, but the enemies' aswell. I liked the investigation mechanic. Story is interesting and so are the serial killer characters. The MC's voice acting isn't that good, but everyone else I thought was fine. The game has a really great atmosphere which in my opinion is the most important part of a horror game (or horror in general). Though personally I never found the game scary (although I am a tough cookie to break.) Even the infamous mannequin section. I found it very amusing one of the collectables were dead birds.I only had one problem when some boards in the attic were supposed to disappear but they didn't, looked it up and solved the issue by waiting till they disappeared like they were supposed to. And with the final boss I didn't know I had to press 1 as it didn't say so when it gave me the indicator to grab him. Plus the game configure tool only has some weird random resolutions, so I had to edit the settings CFG file to run it at 1080, which it runs just fine at. Also keep in mind this game is pretty short, I beat it in just 6 hours. All in all I loved it though primarily just for the combat. I mean I cared enough to write a real review when I usually do stupid joke "reviews" like the opening sentence for this review.

content:
r 18, 2016
												Don't let my playing hours fool you, the game is definitely not this long, i just try to do some no death runs once in a while. Anyway, let me start up by pointing out the flaws of this game.Sure the graphics are decently under mediocre and the story is so bad you can literally pull apart the plot and point out the plot holes to the point of hilarity, but ignoring all that crap nobody cares about... the gameplay is very fun! Theres a melee combat system that really gives you the feeling of OMPH when you whack someone. Watch a killer hobo spit out his rotten teeth after you give him a good whack to the head with a freaking sledgehammer, Watch as your enemy stumbles backwards while being repeatedly pummeled with a pipe you just ripped from the wall like freaking rambo. But the enemies while being homocidial killer hobos aren't completely dumb either, they will try to fake you by pretending to whack you, they will block your attack and return your kindness onto you if you aren't as good as utilizing the blocking mechanic. If you ever get bored of that you can pick up some guns and just shoot them to death instead. The guns has a OMPH feeling to them as well, shooting someone with a pistol in the stomach isn't synonymous with a light tickle like "bullet sponge" enemies in other game but you will watch them stumble backwards in pain, thus giving you that sadistic feeling of dominance and badassness all of us gamer psychos strive for for. The ammo levels for the guns are quite pathetic however, and you are actually unable to reload, so obviously the game prefers us to bash people to death like a real man would. The locations are quite interesting in theme with the "condemned" name of the title, i gotta give them that. Even for horrific graphics they still managed to build up quite the atmosphere of desolation and sometimes even fear. Not many games has this focus on melee so if you buy it this should be your incentive, if you buy it just for the gameplay  and laughing at the b-movie quality storyline you won't be dissapointed at all.

content:
er 10, 2016
												Criminal Origins is a great game still today. It has a good storyline with a little bit of a twist, it isnt the best i have ever played through but together with the gameplay it makes the game good.The combat system is pretty simple, mostly melee but also guns at some times.I would have liked it the game would have been a little bit more scary. It has a few jumpscares but could have needed a something more to give it a even darker tone. Maybe make you use either the flashlight or a weapon.The graphics if you ask me is great for its age. It has a loot of options and you can get the game to look really good if you mess around with them a bit.Cons: I had 2 problems with this game.1. The controlls where pretty much messed up when i tried to play the game. I had to bind my own controlls. It isnt a huge problem but can get a bit annoying after a while.2. The fps, when i first started playing this game the fps was constantly below 30 fps. Which is crazy. But i read about it and it has something to do with the software from the mouse or the keyboard. I didnt really care about it and then suddently the fps went up and the game ran great. So my conclusion of Criminal Origins is that its a good game!Story: 7.5/10Combat system: 8/10Atmosphere: 7/10Graphics: 10/10 (For its age!)Controlls: 5/10I truly recommend this game for anyone that likes games with a little bit of a darker theme, and people that dont care about graphics!

content:
er 23, 2016
Dated Graphics, Solid Gameplay and AtmosphereCondemned: Criminal Origins originally came out in 2005 for the xbox 360, and in some parts of the game, mainly well lit areas and cutscenes, it really shows. But luckily most of these dated graphics are hidden by the dark levels that make up the majority of the game, and these level have a great atmosphere that's perfect for a horror game.There are guns and a taser in this game, but the main feature and reason you will keep coming back is the melee. I don't care how many hours you've spent in this game; it is always satisfying to wallop a hobo upside the head with a pipe.The AI is also great and really adds to the atmosphere. The enemies will make you paranoid and will always keep you guessing, 'Why did he turn and run? Is it still in the room? What's behind me? Why is he asking for chang-'.Though as a downside, once you've finished the game and start replaying it, the investigation mode parts do become tiresome and slow the game down.In all, if you're looking for a horror game that has great melee combat, pick up this little gem. Here's hoping they will add Condemned 2: Bloodshot to Steam.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
r 11, 2016
												When I think back to games I played that are about a decade old I'm filled with nostalgia and warm feelings, even when it comes to games that aren't that warm and fuzzy like Condemned: Criminal Origins I still feel the same and although its a bit ripe now its an old horror title that the first time around gave me much delight in playing.As with most older titles being ported to PC that aren't remastered things can and more often than not do go wrong, however it generally varies from player to player and hardware to hardware. For myself however I suffered tremendously bad Framerate and stuttering issues not to mention missing sound files within certain levels, now normally this is more than enough to turn players off to the idea of continuing their game but i'm nothing if not stubborn and so taking to the community I sure enough found many resourceful souls that had found solutions to the problems and more that I had dealt with, so put simply if you don't mind a bit of tweaking this game can be played from start to finish with grinding your teeth to dust in frustration.Maintenance issues aside this particular title predated Outlast and Amnesia and although it doesn't have the amount of clout that those have it was made with an older engine, even cranked up to maximum you will struggle to tell the difference in graphical quality but I digress gaming is not all about the graphics and the combat style of Condemned encapsulates my point nicely, dealing with the mentally psychotic and deranged populace you will have rarely any ammo to speak off and so it falls to you to use anything and everything you can get your hands on around you before you're ultimately twatted to death by a 2X4, the combat system revolves around speed and your ability to anticipate your opponents next move will he fake or will he just swear at you.What I am saying is that the developer has taken an approach to the combat system rarely seen in modern games in that instead of a enemy utilising cover trying to flank etc, instead these nutters might rush you all at once possibly taking each other out in the process or take to hiding if the fighting's too thick, the enemy you will inevitibly dance with come in a few different flavours and it will be down to you to decide on how best to handle the situation.Aside from the combat there are times where you will need to make use of the many scientific gadgets you carry with you in your bottomless pockets to investigate crime scenes gather evidence and look for clues pertaining to your goal and to further the storyline, all of which is pretty simple and comes with hints on how to use it, the only other thing to do in Condemned is for the completionists out there, scattered around the levels are collectibles in the forms of dead and/or dying birds and curious pieces of metal, why your character would want to carry rotting birds around with him in his pockets is beyond me but hey thats not for me to question.As I said graphically the gameworld isn't pretty but it is a decade old but if you are the kind of gamer who allows themselves to be absorbed into the game they play then allow the ambient sound effects and atmospheric music take you away to a horrid place where death is poised around every corner and who knows perhaps you'll get a jumpscare or two.

content:
y 5, 2016
												This game made me:-Feel like I was playing a 105 year old FBI detective on his deathbed. Seriously, the walking and sprinting speeds are just ridiculous. I am not even mentioning the speed at which stairs & ladders are climbed. -Hate Thomas Ethan's Stamina. WTF! I think a veteran FBI detective should be able to run more than 25 f**king meters before gasping for some air. -Hate those skinny little a**holes that crawl everywhere and scare the damn out of you when they attack. I mean, what are they? Human? Animal? The devil? If human, what the hell affected them like that? Bet it sure wasn't the holy spirit. Other than that, Condemned: Criminal Origins is a decent horror game every horror fan must have. Combat AI is unparalleled and the visuals are stunning for the time of its release.(2006) Though the game might get a little linear for some people, especially towards the end, it compensates for that with it's perfectly timed scares and pschological horror theme.Also the crime scene investigation aspect of the game is an amazing and original idea for a horror game. Simply brilliant!I'd give it a solid 8.5/10.

content:
, 2013
												Condemned: Criminal Origins is a psychological first-person horror game that has managed to stand the test of time as well as any other title from its era. This is thanks in large part to the game's visceral combat system which focuses on melee weapons, as well as an intense atmosphere that will keep you constantly wondering what's just around the corner. This creepy atmopshere is further developed by quality level design and some good use of lighting and sound effects. Enemy AI is mostly intelligent; your psychotic opposition will sneak around quietly, strafe and block effectively, and won't just whale away on you when they see you. However, while the game holds up just fine from a gameplay and mechanics standpoint, there are some muddy textures and awkward character models that are less than appealing when compared to more modern games.If you're looking for a game that can provide some solid thrills and an immensely satisfying combat system, Condemned: Criminal Origins is as good as it gets. An underappreciated title that plays just as well today as it did 7-8 years ago.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
2, 2015
												Aged a bit but the suspense will get to you everytime. Whether that be muffled footsteps upstairs or crushing of rubble and glass behind that corner. Every sound will make you tighten your grip on the 2x4 nail or electric conduit. You can use most of the environment as an weapon. Except Bloodshot really varies what you can use better. The brawling action is addicting except for the momentary block making it difficult if you block at the wrong time. The enemies don't have attack patterns and will deceive you whenever they can. Dodging, attacking twice, hiding behind corners when you aren't looking, whatever they can do to beat you. That makes you hesitate sometimes which I love. Again Bloodshot has more random patterns whether that is a pro or a con. And finally the story is immersive but inconclusive. I like how Rosa isn't reading a book to you. Every clue leads to another piece of the story. Feels like you are doing an actual investigation. This made me spawn a bunch of theories about what happened, where they went, etc. Short summary: Immersive but inconclusive story, addicting brawling combat with varying makeshift weapons, and heart-pounding suspense. 8.7/10

It's not like that at all, honest!Also there's a sequence where you dangle off the back of a subway train that actually ♥♥♥♥ing terrifies me because I was conditioned to equate being anywhere near a train but on-board it as a death sentence. Atmos so good.

												I can't believe I didn't hear about this game until 9 years after release. The graphics are obviously a bit aged, but imo they hold up very well, unlike most titles of it's day. The combat takes some getting used to, but once you learn timing your moves it becomes a lot of fun. Especially since these enemies -will- irritate you enough that you'll want to beat them to death with a gas pipe.The storyline is quite interesting. It's like a mash-up of Silent Hill, Bioshock, and Outlast. It's got enough depth and quick shot moments that you'll want to pay attention.  My one complaint? The obvious one: No Condemned 2 for PC. Bad move considering you'll want to play the sequel immediately after this.

content:
14, 2015
												finally finished it, and now I can write a review. You may think that this is an FPS game, but you would be wrong! This game has guns, but they kinda suck. You can only have as much ammo as the gun came with, the only way to get more ammo is to get a different gun. Melee combat is the games focus. Combat is simple, but fun. You can hit, block and use your taser. You also have 4 different execution moves when the enemy is on his knees. The main problem I have with this game is that the movement controls are clunky and slow. You have two speeds, snail and snail that has been pushed by another snail, and your stamina bar runs out VERY quickly. And don't get me started on walking on the stairs... dear god. The game is also very creepy and there are some parts that will give you a mini heart attack. Walking around in the darkness with the only source of light being from your flashlight and hearing guys in the distance yelling at eachother and killing eachother is uncomforatable and unsettling. Then you walk around a corner and some hobo with a shotgun is standing there with you in his sights. TL;DR : Get this game, its amazing and you wont regret buying it. And I forgot to mention the story, its also pretty interesting and you probably would want to see what happens later. Now I have to go and finish the sequel...

												An absolute gem of a first-person action game. Gritty and atmospheric with the best melee combat I've experienced in any game. It's a suspensful game, not because of jump scares but because of the atmosphere it builds around you. The enemy AI is top notch too.Example: Walking through a dirty, dank subway station I turn a corner to catch a glimpse of a drug addict duck behind a stone column. As I enter the room he opens fire; I duck behind the nearest column. Both guns and ammo are scarce in this game, so I knew I could weather the storm. A few shots, pause, he's reloading. He comes out again, one, two, three...four, five, six shots. I bolt out from behind the column and hit him square in the chest with a sledgehammer as he's reloading his pistol.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 3, 2014
												Let Monolith take you through a joyride with creepy atmosphere, scary visual effects that keep you on edge, a great story, and satisfying gameplay. Condemned Criminal Origins is a game where you play as FBI Detective Ethan Thomas who is framed by a serial killer for the deaths of his fellow officers. The only thing he can do is prove his innocence by tracking down the killer. But it's not a simple walk in the park, along the way you will fight violent civilians whose number has been growing in the city recently.The enemies themselves are so scary because they seem like regular people from far away but every time you get close to take a swing you see their messed up demonic faces. It's really cool. The enemies kind of behave how I imagine crack heads would. They usually have a melee weapon with them but they can, if forced to, grab a weapon from the map. Combat is really satisfying as you can swing, block (which causes a stun if done successfully), and kick. It's kind of like Kirby games because you can get different weapons mid-level that you choose depending on your mood (except for the scary crack heads). There are also guns in the game. Both you and the enemy can use it. The guns are more like a Get out of jail free card because it usually kills an enemy with one shot. There's also a taser but it's similar to the gun because it makes things too easy (except for one situation).The investigation scenes are also better than the ones in F.E.A.R. In F.E.A.R you are given more pieces to the puzzle of what is going on by pushing E on a computer and letting your friend talk about what you found. In this game you have to use forensic tools to find the clues rather than hit a simple button. For me it’s more satisfying to use the tools because you actually see the evidence and hear the results of its analysis.Only con of the game is that your character walks SO SLOW. His sprint is as fast as a normal walking speed but it only lasts 5 seconds. This is bad for two reasons. One there are collectable birds and metal pieces that you can find in the level. How do you expect me to explore when I am so slow. I go to a place where I think there will be a bird, there isn't, I try to run back to the path but I run out of sprint, I cry from frustration. The second reason why the running speed is bad is because some enemies (only a few each level) have guns. So you have to run towards them and take them out but you can't do that because you are so slow. The only way around it is to use a gun or the taser.Nonetheless this is a great horror game that gets under your skin rather than relies on jump scares. Definitely get it if you like F.E.A.R.

content:
19, 2016
												In Condemned: Criminal Origins, the goal of the game is to move through mostly linear, filthy buildings in an urban environment, occasionally deviating from the obvious path to pick up meaningless collectibles, such as engraved pieces of metal and dead birds. During these treks, the player uses a variety of improvised and non-improvised weaponry to fend off legions of greasy hobos, pale-skinned crack ♥♥♥♥♥s, acrobats who cosplay as Sméagol, and f̶a̶t̶t̶i̶e̶s̶ tumblr users. There are light elements of forensic and puzzle gameplay that keep the story going, a narrative which is surprisingly easy to follow. The game is plagued by awkward combat, usually the fault of indiscernible attack reach, as well as a number of weird design choices. Some sort of make sense, in sacrificing logic for the sake of gameplay. I can understand why the player isn't allowed to pick up ammo, as the guns give a huge advantage, but other times it looks the developers got lazy in their planning. Why are there so many invisible walls? Why do defeated enemies take so long to telegraph their helplessness before I get options to perform special finishes? Why is there even a toggle for the flashlight? Actually, I take that back. There is only one reason to ever turn the flashlight off: when a pronounced visual effect comes onto the screen and intensifies the already high contrast. Otherwise, it might as well be kept on for the entire game. Often, it's dark enough to justify using it, it's not on a timer so it can be used whenever, and it doesn't do anything to alert the enemies to my presence. In fact, the enemies might as well not even exist until I pass a certain invisble threshold and they spring into the level with their canned, predictable routines. That's my main issue with this game, is how nearly every moment designed to deliver on the suspense is a triggered event which usually fails in this endeavor. Sure, other things, like cleverly-placed objects to trip over and ominously-moving furniture help to build that sense of dread, but when it comes time to actually scare the player, it's frequently something that can be seen a mile ahead of time, such as the truck-sized blobs of meat that think they can hide behind corners without getting stuck on said corners. Yet, as much as I've been ripping it a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this one is alright, at least for one playthrough. It's an odd combination of atmosphere, combat, and puzzles that would seem mediocre on their own, but coagulate here into a unique, if at first glance lackluster, experience.

content:
r 11, 2016
												When I think back to games I played that are about a decade old I'm filled with nostalgia and warm feelings, even when it comes to games that aren't that warm and fuzzy like Condemned: Criminal Origins I still feel the same and although its a bit ripe now its an old horror title that the first time around gave me much delight in playing.As with most older titles being ported to PC that aren't remastered things can and more often than not do go wrong, however it generally varies from player to player and hardware to hardware. For myself however I suffered tremendously bad Framerate and stuttering issues not to mention missing sound files within certain levels, now normally this is more than enough to turn players off to the idea of continuing their game but i'm nothing if not stubborn and so taking to the community I sure enough found many resourceful souls that had found solutions to the problems and more that I had dealt with, so put simply if you don't mind a bit of tweaking this game can be played from start to finish with grinding your teeth to dust in frustration.Maintenance issues aside this particular title predated Outlast and Amnesia and although it doesn't have the amount of clout that those have it was made with an older engine, even cranked up to maximum you will struggle to tell the difference in graphical quality but I digress gaming is not all about the graphics and the combat style of Condemned encapsulates my point nicely, dealing with the mentally psychotic and deranged populace you will have rarely any ammo to speak off and so it falls to you to use anything and everything you can get your hands on around you before you're ultimately twatted to death by a 2X4, the combat system revolves around speed and your ability to anticipate your opponents next move will he fake or will he just swear at you.What I am saying is that the developer has taken an approach to the combat system rarely seen in modern games in that instead of a enemy utilising cover trying to flank etc, instead these nutters might rush you all at once possibly taking each other out in the process or take to hiding if the fighting's too thick, the enemy you will inevitibly dance with come in a few different flavours and it will be down to you to decide on how best to handle the situation.Aside from the combat there are times where you will need to make use of the many scientific gadgets you carry with you in your bottomless pockets to investigate crime scenes gather evidence and look for clues pertaining to your goal and to further the storyline, all of which is pretty simple and comes with hints on how to use it, the only other thing to do in Condemned is for the completionists out there, scattered around the levels are collectibles in the forms of dead and/or dying birds and curious pieces of metal, why your character would want to carry rotting birds around with him in his pockets is beyond me but hey thats not for me to question.As I said graphically the gameworld isn't pretty but it is a decade old but if you are the kind of gamer who allows themselves to be absorbed into the game they play then allow the ambient sound effects and atmospheric music take you away to a horrid place where death is poised around every corner and who knows perhaps you'll get a jumpscare or two.

												The game is. Good.  a straight 3/5 that neither wowed me nor gave me less than expected.  Since it paved the way for the xbox 360, one needs to keep in mind it's release date.  The game did startle me time to time and I did feel a sense of dread through its entirety, but when you get down to it, its a simple melee beatemup with some extra elements thrown in. r 31, 2015
												...Great game...1st game I ever played on the 360 in 2006. Just as good today. But here are the few frustrating game quirks you will have to deal with... The block mechanic, no matter how hard to try to master & analyse it...it will so often be your undoing, it will be your demise so often..it is a severe problem, I learned to play without it in the end...attack then back-peddle worked much better. Sprint/run can also not be trusted...it feels like and acts like there is glue on the souls of your shoes...very odd. Next, once in a while when the AI & I were using the same weapon type, my melee reach was about a 1/2 or a 1/3 of their impact range. I really noticed this is the 'Orchard' level where we all used flaming torches as melee weapons. I had to get within about 4ft for a hit to register but they could hit me between 10-12ft away...that seemed very cheap & a real cheat by the game mechanics. Finally, you will always slow down to a crawl on stairs & you will often stick on the most minor of steps...odd as steps/stairs will not slow the AI...    Other than those oddities it's well worth a play thru...a short game which took me 5hrs in total to complete....so in the end recommended :-)

												Cool game for it's time. Eerie kind of atmospheric FPS. A lot of melee combat, though. And even more crawling around figuring out which way to go. I think it still holds up mostly, even with dated graphics(volumetric lighting though, what's up). But game's greatly flawed. It feels clunky and rigid. Also game frequently takes your weapon away in cutscenes and such. And when you treasure every bullet it can get you mad. You only have as many bullets, as you find already loaded in a gun, but your opponents can reload theirs. Sometimes there are no sound effects too. The cutscene on train is almost fully silent. What's up with that? I did not finish the game, since apparently i can't move at the start of chapter 7, but still i had some fun.

content:
10
												To me, this game hasn't aged a day. The melee combat is as fresh as ever except for the odd AI glitch or two or three. Pro reviews cited weakness in the weapon sounds and textures, as well as an overall unremarkableness to the game's decor. I do not see this as a weakness but as a return to form for the video game medium where a wall is a wall, not a symbol for industrial greatness or self-triumph, but rather, just a wall. It looks like the wall next to it, a wall which serves a purpose similar in function to the floor and ceiling, and just as vulnerable to destruction. Not that there is any player-controlled destruction of environments but enemies will try it out on the player while the game complements the chaos with drywall particles and dust from rotted wood. It's true that it could be called "duller" than some brighter-colored alternatives but the side-benefit is an easing-in experience where you are hypnotized more than shocked. I liken it, personally, to a water-color pallette.The game is decidedly lo-fi in some aspects but spares no expense procuring top-tier voice actors that deliver stolid and enjoyable performances. If you're a stickler for certainty, you may pass, as the story will leave you scratching your head somewhat. Deeper exploration will reward you with collectible quests that unlock further background information accessible through the main menu, as well as concept art from internal circulation at Monolith.Overall, a 4/5 game that you will enjoy many times over if you enjoy its core mechanic of bludgeoning homeless people's faces in with a nailboard.

content:
y 14
												Man, this is a weird one. It's all love and hate for me. It tries to be a first-person brawler, shooter, detective and a horror, and neither of that it does well. It has some of the weirdest collectibles I've ever seen(dead birds for instance), unskippable cutscenes and OH MY GOD this game loves to waste the player's time - walking and even running speeds are infuriatingly slow(stamina bar is included, of course), and every time the character goes up or down a minimal slope(this includes all stairs), movement speed is reduced even further to unbelievable, rage-inducing crawl. This actively punishes exploration, which wasn't all that meaningful to begin with. Not to mention the plot, which makes very little sence and average at best writing.However, it still clicked with me. The game is genuinely creepy and very atmospheric, and thankfully horror does not rely too heavily on cheap jump scares. Combat, while not fleshed out mechanically very well, is visceral and heavy-hitting, and suprsingly good animations and gritty, realistic sound effects help immerse further into this weird experience. The very last level felt somewhat rushed and poorly presented, but nevertheless was an immensly satisfying conclusion, due to relying on the game's stronger points. Overall, I can't either praise or damn this game. It's hit-or-miss, and I was an inch away from giving it a negative review. At least it tries to be original, and I'd say mostly it succeeds.
